summary: After months have passed without a culprit in her daughter's murder case, Mildred Hayes makes a bold move, painting three signs leading into her town with a controversial message directed at William Willoughby, the town's revered chief of police. When his second-in-command, Officer Dixon -- an immature mother's boy with a penchant for violence -- gets involved, the battle is only exacerbated.

reviews.content: A fantastic film. Great performances, dark and humorous. One of my all time favourites now.
It doesn't have a good ending it needs better ending and twisted bad movie very disappointing
I was almost put off by the boring title, but I gave it a go and it turned out to be a lot better than I expected.
A movie full of horrible, vulgar people with no redeeming value. Another of Hollywood's twisted vision of Middle America.

Great performances lost in the muck. Way too much cussing (Is the writer a 14 year old boy?), that was distracting and not necessary. No explanation on why the guy chooses to go thru fire rather than use the backdoor of the building. The story had the  essentials for a great Shakespearean play but had too many holes.

McDonagh is a master of style and atmosphere but here I feel he was out of his element tackling distinctly American social issues ultimately too big to receive proper treatment as filaments in a muddled tapestry. As a result there are several ham fisted attempts to beat the audience bluntly over the head in order to point out themes which the thoughtful viewer should already have been aware were boiling in the background. A well made film from every technical and artistic angle which I felt failed to deliver any meaningful message, unlike masterpieces Bruges and Banshees, which exhibit what McDonagh is capable of on more comfortable turf. Likewise, where Seven Psychopaths succeeded due to its willingness to not take itself seriously, here McDonagh attempts to expand on his foothold of Americana by injecting the more emotional elements of his typical work into that violent wacky comedic framework - and fails to bridge the gap.

The film has a creative concept and powerfully realized characters. It's dark and serious and well thought out. The small-town community feels very realistic, and all the side characters add something to the story. The central performances are powerful, especially Frances McDormand's. I like how nuanced the character is – while she's sympathetic she isn't necessarily good. Martin McDonagh's signature dark humor is also present. The laughs are carefully sprinkled throughout and don't detract from the serious subject matter.

A gruesome murder rocks a small town, leaving no apparent suspects. The film captures the aftermath of the crime from the perspective of a tough, emotionally distant mother. Her character is multi-faceted, initially coming across as unyielding, but as the plot unfolds, her actions reveal a sense of childlike desperation as she seeks answers for the act.

This movie boasts a powerful plot that delves into a range of issues, such as race, morality, rape, domestic violence, and the painful grief associated with murder. However, despite the dark nature of the story, the film injects rare but dry humor into the mix, creating moments of levity amidst the emotional fallout.

Above all, "Three Billboards Outside Ebbing" is a captivating exploration of mid western small-town America. The plot is gripping, the humor is sharp, and the performances are top-notch.

The fictional town of Ebbing, Missouri takes centre stage in Martin McDonagh's gritty story of one mother's quest for justice in this intense crime drama. The film has been decades in the making, when McDonagh was first inspired by accusatory billboards in 1998, asking about the murder of a woman named Kathy Page. Assuming the billboards were put up by Kathy's mother inspired McDonagh, combined with his desire to create strong female characters. Academy Award winner Frances McDormand leads a talented cast that includes Woody Harrelson, Sam R ockwell, Peter Dinklage, and Lucas Hedges.

Seven months after the rape and murder of her daughter Angela, Mildred Hayes (McDormand) is frustrated with the lack of progress in finding her daughter's killer and decides to take matters into her own hands. She rents three billboards near her home as a way to ask the police department why no progress has been made in the investigation, calling out police chief Bill Willoughby (Woody Harrelson) by name. As expected, the billboards rattle the population of Ebbing, with Mildred being harassed daily, but one person takes particular issue with the billboards, Officer Jason Dixon (Sam Rockwell). As tensions in the small town grow, Mildred begins taking extreme risks to ensure justice is served, but will her determined efforts be successful, or will her daughter's murder remain unsolved?

Frances McDormand's Oscar-winning performances is arguably one of the actress' best turns in recent years. She portrays the grieving mother as the impulsive and resolute woman she is, creating a character that audiences can really sink their teeth into. Sam Rockwell brings the complex character of Jason Dixon to the screen, earning the "Moon" actor his first Academy Award. Rockwell's turn as the controversial police officer makes for one of the film's many highlights, even more so during an intense one take scene in which Dixon goes on a rampage which him violently throwing Red Welby (Caleb Landry Jones) out of a window. The powerful performances from McDormand and Rockwell are joined by a marvellous turn from Woody Harrelson as the Ebbing police chief, and a criminally underused Peter Dinklage.

Writer and director Martin McDonagh creates an impressive screenplay that perfectly balances the film's hilarious black comedy with intense and emotional drama. However, the film's ending can't help but feel like a little bit of a let-down, as if McDonagh couldn't figure out how to end the film or if he just gave up, leaving audiences to guess what happened. Cinematographer Ben Davis ("Eternals", "Cry Macho") crafts gorgeous visuals, and combined with the crisp editing, courtesy of "In Bruges" editor Jon Gregory make "Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri" an extremely enjoyable visual experience, even if you're not invested in the story.

If it wasn't obvious from the film's premise, "Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri" is a searing story about how far a woman will go to get the justice she deserves, with Mildred turning to burning down the police station in order to get her message across. However, the fact that Mildred had to put up the accusatory billboards is potentially a testament to how, sometimes, the police can be lazy when it comes to investigating certain cases, which can be backed up by the fact that Sam Rockwell's Officer Dixon doesn't take his job seriously, with the character reading comics and messing about until he's fired.

Martin McDonagh delivers a tour de force with this 2017 crime drama. Showcasing knockout performances from both Frances McDormand and Sam Rockwell, the film tells a harrowing story of one woman on her quest to get justice for her daughter's brutal rape and murder. With McDonagh's next directorial effort "The Banshees of Inisherin" set to be released later this year, we can only hope that the British-Irish director's skills transfer effectively from this gritty drama to a 1920s comedy drama set in Ireland.

This crime drama, with more than a dash of McDonagh's trademark black wit, is a film about anger leading to anger and the unintended consequences thereof. It's a beautifully constructed script, character and plot beats paced out with subtle precision; and it looks subtly beautiful, cinematography, colour and lighting coalescing to haunting effects. It feels redundant to say that Frances McDormand is superb; at this point in her career, she's an actor whose excellence is guaranteed. It's also more than a little influenced by the crime dramas of the Coen brothers - in tone, plot and much else, it's easy to imagine this as one of theirs. All the characters in this film feel as if they're trapped in a situation they want out of but can't navigate the way, their solutions are always just out of reach. It's as melancholy as it is funny, and it's never short of compassionate human insight.

Arguably McDonagh's finest work to date, Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri paints a dark, engrossing, and brilliantly written portrait of the American midwest, and features outstanding performances from the entire cast, especially that of Frances McDormand, Woody Harrelson, and Sam Rockwell.

Apparently contrary to most reviewers, this movie left me completely dissatisfied. Not only with the plot, but also with the characters. I found myself looking for someone who at least had some sense, some hope, and what's more important: to have at least some idea of a morale. But this search was in vain. So, it wasn't my cup of tea for sure. But I guess that cynical nihilists with a dark sense of humor will find it's taste and temperature just right.
Amazing movie!!! Gripping, thrilling.. masterpiece!
One of the best movies I've seen in a decade

I like the plot, it's a revenge drama but not straight, intereresting use characters. The ending is obscure. At first glance depressing, but not entirely sad nor violent because there is humanity at the same time. Effective use of visual elements to progress the story, and it's not too obvious. Excellent performance by actors. Total control by the director/writer.
The best acting ever by an ensemble, including the best acting performance from Sam Rockwell! With the best casting ever done in a movie!
Loved this film and the cast was amazing!
This movie is absolutely outstanding! I did not expect this movie to be heartfelt, hilarious, and absolutely captivating as it was. My God the acting… Sensational!

Martin McDonagh's Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri is a wonderfully constructed, searingly beautiful and thought-provoking drama which blendes a lot of varietive genre elements in a superb picture with electrifying performances, wicked cinematography and terrific screenplay all assure that this is one of the most critically acclaimed and lovable films of 2017.

Not really a movie that makes any sense. Why would someone who makes so little offer to pay so much for billboards? And the end is just a bad joke. 

If this had been based on a true story, ok, perhaps... but it's not and it is an al round dissapointment. 80% of this movie is good, but the remaining 20% is so stupid, the spoils the rest.

Heart-warming family drama with overwhelming emotions around a town with great advertising ideas haha... with a heavy seasoning of bad words, jokes, anger and plenty over the lines then gone wrongs...

Three Billboards Outside Ebbing Missouri is good.  I wasn't on board until after the first act, but I'm glad I stayed for this unpredictable ride.

It's silly and serious, funny and sad, dark and uncomfortable at times, with a tone that's difficult to pin down.

Pretentious and melodramatic, could've been far better if the director had dialled it down a couple of notches.

I finally got around to watching this film and ended up being disappointed.  The set-up is terrific: the billboards, the unspeakable crime, the victim's mother and her implacable anger. Woody Harrelson brings complexity to his portral of the besieged police chief and you're all set for a deeply satisfying tense portrait of the effects of this tragedy on the members of the town, or so you think....

There are those moments in a a book or movie that strike a wrong note and you discount them - maybe it was just me? - then another one happens and another....  The wrong notes for me were the characters doing things that real people simply don't do.  When the police chief confesses to the bereaved mother that he has cancer her bitter callous response is shocking.  Hmm, okay so she's a REAL hardarse. Then she attacks and mutilates the dentist because he suggests she should take the billboards down.  This is almost played for laughs but it's okay because....he's fat? And therefore ridiculous and so it doesn't really matter if he's mutilated because of a careless remark.  It gets worse, no one seems to care that she did this, certainly not the police, they seem to think he had it coming.  Police departments simply do not work like this. Later when a cop smashes windows and almost kills a citizen - right across the road from the police station whats more - passersby seem to barely notice, certainly not the new hot shot cop in town who seems only mildly interested.  There is no outcry, his fellow officers don;t rein him him in which they would do even for there own sakes so as not to bring themselvs into disrespect. However the new hot shot cop does get to deliver some cool lines in a a cartoonish exchange that had me nearly rolling my eyes at the absurdity of it.

I diagnosed what I think is the problem fairly early on. Director McDonagh is Irish and as an outsider has learned what he knows about America by watching movies and TV shows and to me lacks the subtlety and understanding of the culture he seeks to examine. Like fellow theatre director Sam Mendes' patronising American Beauty he trades in egregious stereotypes - the stupid racist white cop, the cool black lieutenant, the drunken toothless hick mother  - but  presents it as if he's giving you the "real deal" on the "real America". 

The theatre background explains a lot, everything is turned up to 11 all the time, McDonagh needed to ease it back and give the actors and material some space.  It came across like a Tarantino movie at times - "pointless sadistic violence is cool! It doesn't even really hurt!" - and Wild at Heart era David Lynch with city actors portraying small town people as a bunch of two-dimensional yokels.  You can see McDonagh is trying to avoid cliches and stock characters but what he ends up doing is taking stock characters to begin with and then simply making them to unlikely things.  

I'm not even American and I found it patronising and ultimately quite silly.

Hard hitting / daring / courageous / heart braking must see film.
Simple story plot, complicated characters & people. This fine entanglement has produced one serious masterpiece.
Be critical & also be kind!
I find this to be one of the best drama films. It has it all, it's funny, dark, sad, and it shows a different face from grieve. A must-watch for sure.
I liked it. It definitely felt like a movie made specifically for the Academy Awards, but it was still good.

As a character drama and mystery film its quite good. I felt the mothers strength and determinism came through well and indeed Frances McDormand gave a great performance in this film. Its not so much about the details of what happened to her daughter who was sadly killed, its more about local police departments, small American town life and the like. There are some plot twists and its a fairly thoughtful film too. Well worth a watch - I'd recommend this.

A rare movie of such enthralling and realistic story-telling about human nature that if there were flaws in character development or other aspects, they were just overshadowed by sheer impact of the actors.
A dark satire of a difficult theme, that delivers an incredible performances.

This movie deserved to be seen even only for the acting and the soundtrack. There is no closure, you never get a true ending, but that doesn't matter because its about the journey, not the destination. The storytelling is really good and achieves what it aims to. Overall its a great movie!
Masterful performances across the board!

This movie was tensed and totally unpredictable. The story unfolds slowly, giving us time to get to know about each character. The performances by the leads was brilliant, that's why they won the oscars for the performances. The story, direction, everything was good. Overall, a great movie.
this is the shittiest, most pretentious, unrealistic, grotesque, unenjoyable movie I've every watched. I'd hate to be around the kind of people who would come up with a movie like this
The most original American movie in recent years. Extremely direct about existence, in a mixture of absurd comedy and pure tragedy. Brilliant cast and obviously made with great affection.

When the police give up their investigation of the rape and murder of a young girl, her mother challenges the police by placing three billboards just outside of town calling for action.

This is a film that I had never even remotely heard of until today, which is why I decided to watch it, and I was pleasantly surprised to find an amazing film.

The two things that I love most about this film are the setting and the characters. This film takes place in a small town and for a film that was released in 2017 the dialogue consists of a lot of risky things, things that most people are scared to say. But that's whats so great about it, they go for it and don't hold back so you get these very open characters that don't care what they say and it makes for some extremely good scenes. 

The lead character Mildred played by Frances McDormand is this foul mouthed, broken but fearless mother, that doesn't take smack from anyone. Frances is phenomenal as this character and gives one of the best performances I've seen in a more modern film. Woodie Harrelson and Sam Rockwell are also extremely good in their respective roles. Although he wasn't in it much I enjoyed the scenes involving Peter Dinklages character, made for some hilarious moments.

Martin McDonagh the writer and director is incredible, she sets up this town extremely well and gives us some great cinematography along with it. 

The film is also unpredictable, I kept thinking I knew what was going to happen next but was very surprised when what happened wasn't what I expected. 

If you are a legitimate movie fan you will enjoy this film. The way it dives into the setting and the characters is extremely well done and entertaining. If you are looking for more of a action filled fun ride I'd probably skip this one. 

My one gripe with the film is the ending. I was extremely invested in Mildred and when the film ended although I don't think it's a bad ending, I was hoping for something a little more neat. I wish they could've given us just one more scene to rap it up just a little better. But all in all an incredible film.

9.5/10

mediocre movie for me. something missing

Three Billboards works as a drama: it takes on deeply serious topics with painstaking care and memorable dramatic power. It also works as a black comedy. Unfortunately, those two elements don't always come together seamlessly, and some of the comedic moments (particularly involving Dixon) district from the otherwise sharp drama. Even if Three Billboards is slightly less than the sum of its parts, however, its parts are of such high quality that the film is a must-watch.
Pretty dark all the way to the end but the characters are great and the movie has something to say
Awesome movie and cast.

Torn between three and four stars. I went with three because I think the movie lacked a driving plot. Rather than there being a lot of focus on solving her daughter's murder, the movie is really about an ornery older woman fighting with the town and nearly everyone in it. It was not an entirely uninteresting story, but it was not what I expected from the summary and trailer.

A dark and gritty story about grief. Three billboards outside Ebbing Missouri is a well-crafted story about grief, what it can do to individuals and how we cope with it. The all-star cast and the beautiful thought provoking writing are what make this movie worth your time. I however feel like they could've done a lot more, this movie would've improved tenfold if they elaborated more on the relationships between characters. The pacing at times also felt quite slow, lot of scenes could've either taken less time or used said time in a more efficient way. Yet, that can all be excused for the magnificent way the characters and script portray such raw emotions. Thee billboards outside of Ebbing Missouri is a heart touching story that shines incredibly bright in certain departments, but isn't flawless by any means.

Martin McDonagh hasn't made a bad film yet, and I would suggest all three of his directed feature films are excellent. Seven Psychopaths (2012) might be the one that doesn't quite hit the heights that predecessor and debut In Bruges (2008) does, but there's plenty of evidence to suggest that not many films since the turn of 2000 can better In Bruges. Three Billboards does its best, and although the subject matter is bleak ( A desperate divorced mother bankrolling an ad campaign to find her daughter's killer) McDonagh's incredible ability to weave such blatant black humour around the narrative is spellbinding. You will laugh a hell of a lot during Three Billboards, and Frances McDormand is truly worthy of her best actress gong, but you will also be thrown through every emotion going. I cannot wait to see what Martin McDonagh does next.

There is no doubt that Francis is a very good actress winning an Academy Award for the Movie "Fargo" and she shines as everywhere thus giving this movie a 4 & 1/2 star    
 rating!!!!
Who wrote these characters and dialogs? Nothing but caricatures.

Great film. Great story, great characters, great acting. In fact it's so good that if you didn't like it there's probably something seriously wrong with you.
Go see a doctor.

I enjoyed this blackest of comedies but didn't quite find it to be quite on the same level as the accolades would suggest (and certainly not as good as McDonagh's previous In Bruges). McDormand and Harrelson are fantastic as the grieving mother and the small town police chief with an (open) secret, and there are smatterings of both funny and genuinely moving moments throughout. What held it back for me was the final wishy-washy conclusions the film seemed to draw about anger and acceptance.

I found this movie imaginative from the genre. It doesn't have a precise plot, bit the thing about this movie that I found spectacular is how they managed to create an incredible revenge story just from three billboards. Their is no plot, but the things that make the story is the consequences of each acts and that is what is nice with the story. No real story, just a coherent enchainement of acts that lead to others. The characters development are just perfect. Every character evolves during the movie. The best exemple is Dickson. He changes of personality when he faced the problems of his personality and that was incredible. Also, every characters play a role in the story and none of them are useless. The actors are outstanding in their performances especially McDormand. It is a brilliant, violent, entertaining, sometimes funny and a tragic drama. A must see!
This movie is raw, honest, and the acting and filming is perfect. Highly, highly recommend.

Although the topic may not be for everyone, this is a very good piece of film making, in my humble opinion.
McDormand delivers here one of her finest performance as a boiling hot mother who's just lost her daughter in a horrible crime.
Definitely one of the best film to come out in 2017.
Gripping movie and a trio of strong performances from Frances McDormand, Sam Rockwell and Woody Harrelson. A must watch.

Three Billboards goes to some pretty dark places, but the film's black humour stops it from being too depressing. Woody Harrelson, Sam Rockwell and Francis McDormand all give absolutely stellar performances. I would have liked a more resolved ending, but in a film with so much moral ambiguity perhaps it makes sense not to give us tidy answers.

With an enthralling performances by Frances McDormand and Sam Rockwell, this movie is an incredible representation of non targeted anger, as all of the characters have it, and they are all in the right. I think, though, that its also about humanity, and the "little moments" and where characters show it. I also thought it was interesting having one central idea that everyone is angry about, but not really talking about it. I would definitely recommend this movie to anyone that liked Fargo, and not just because of Frances McDormand.
Frances McDormand shines in this movie, and keeps up with the runaway train of a plot. This movie definitely keeps you on your toes, and is almost hard to keep up with in its rolling chaos.

Really enjoyable.
a drama with a splash of humor
The best movie I’ve ever seen in my life.

LOVED THIS MOVIE goddam. Frances McDormand is becoming my favorite actress. Enjoyable and loved seeing where the direction was gonna go bc this stuff is crazyyy as a motha... lol. The only thing stopping from that full on 5 star is that ending smh. Movie is good as a whole. 9.9/10 LMAO that .1 is that ending.

Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri dramatic story - balanced with great dark comedy moments - delivers Oscar-worthy performances from Frances Mcdormand and Sam Rockwell punching you in the stomach while doing so.
An excellent film about humanity, for sure will mark you.
The idea, the acting and the directing were all so cohesive and fantastic. Absolutely loved it

'Three Billboards" is a dark comedy that is a little too dark for me.  I can't fault the acting, directing, cinematography or script.  Not every dark aspect of human nature or the human condition needs to be explored, highlighted, and exploited by filmmakers.  I was sorry I spent two hours with this film.
Good, but not as good as the Coen Bros films it tries to imitate

Maybe the best film I've ever seen. The visual cinematography will blow you away. The screenplay tackles dark topics directly but is, surprisingly, able to balance it and leave you feeling light with wit, humor, and charmingly complex characters. A brilliant lead heroine, incredible acting, and complex characters with compelling character arcs. Any American will be able to relate to this film.
Powerful movie, great performances of all actors involved, I really enjoyed it!

2021-3-3 Sheriff Willoughby killed himself and left 3 letters. One  for Mildred who was not very happy  about him. The other one for Dixon which really turned him to a decent person. Anger begets greater anger. Yeah, and very tiring actually. But I think when you were in anger, you wouldn't know it was also  painful until you got a hint and starting to forgive and let go. And  then you finally felt released. It's  too tiring to be in anger as much longer as you want.

So the best way to watch this movie is to not know what it's about — it's one of those that's best served unknown and just let the film take you for the ride. All you need to know is that it's got a dream cast of Francis McDormand, Woody Harrelson, and Sam Rockwell. All three of these actors are top notch, and I'll go out o my way to see a most movies that any of these three are billed in. 

Also, this is the most Coen Brothers' movie that the Coen Brothers didn't make. It clearly pulls a TON of inspiration from the likes of Big Lebowski, No Country for Old Men, and especially Fargo, just without the snow. 

I love Francis McDormand. She's easily one of my top three favorite actresses of all time, and this just might be my favorite role of hers. She plays a hardened and grieving mother who lost her daughter to a murder/rape. And throughout the whole movie, you can see her pain, but also her anger. And all she has to live for is to see justice brought down on whoever committed the crime against her poor young daughter. 

And it's the type of film that's filled with colorful characters who are all connected to this tragedy in one way or another. And it's also the kind of movie where no one in particular is the bad guy. I mean, Sam Rockwell does play a loose cannon of a cop, but as Woody Harrelson, as the chief, keeps saying, he's a good guy at heart. Now, I love this movie, but there's no proof or byline that actually suggests that Dixon is good in any way. 

Throughout the movie he proves to be a racist buffoon who fights unfairly and just has a big chip on his shoulder. He does some things in this movie that in real life, he would have been arrest for, yet he gets discharged for a very small offense. So that would be my problem with the movie, is that it's not consistent with the Sam Rockwell's character of Dixon. 

Don't get me wrong, Rockwell is great in his role. He convinces me that he really is a lowlife who needs to be socked in the teeth, but I feel like he's written too conveniently to help the story along where it needs to go. 

Now, despite there being a dark shadow looming over this movie, what with the rape and murder of Mildred's daughter and Chief Willouby's terminal cancer, and the personal pain that every character is dealing with in their own lives, it's still a funny movie. There are unexpected punchlines, and brilliant comedic timing. And perhaps that's WHY the jokes work in this movie, because they contrast so much with the otherwise dour mood of this film. 

There's a scene where Mildred, Frances McDormand, walks into her house and she's all, "Hey, Robbie, I think that midget wants to get in my pants. Father Montgomery." And there's the priest sitting in her kitchen. Her line delivery and shock was just perfect. 

Woody Harrelson as the police chief, is just great as usual. He plays it both tough and friendly. He finds such a great balance, especially while his character is dealing with dying soon and his good name being being borderline slandered because of what's written on the billboards. 

Again, there's no real antagonists in this movie, and usually when a movie is devoid of antagonists, that means that it's got complex characters in its place, and that's exactly what this movie has. These are usually the best types of movies, because complex characters, like real people, are often unpredictable, and unpredictability goes a long way in making a great movie. 

And because this is a better movie than most, it even goes into the backstory of Mildred's failed marriage, and she comes face-to-face with her abusive husband who's dealing with his grief in his own way by driving fancy cars and banging 19 year olds.

I'm not ashamed to admit, I relate to Mildred. Thankfully I haven't lost a child, but life has turned me against people and made me calloused in a lot of ways. I'm not as outspoken as her, or as condescending, but she really has a tender heart. She flips a cockroach over that's stuck on its back, she admires the beauty and purity of a wandering deer in the field and she talks to it. 

I'm usually cranky most days because I'm not where I thought I'd be in my life. I'm working on it, but yeah, I've got anger issues. However, I'll bring home lost kittens and swerve out of the way of a bird in the road. My daughter and I buried a dead mole we found outside just a few weeks ago. 

So yeah, I related to Mildred. And I think everyone will find a character to relate to in this movie, that's how diverse the characters are. 

Now, as great of an actor as Woody Harrelson is, I don't think he does voice over very well. After he kills himself the rest of the movie sort of relies on him reading his separate suicide notes to each person in his life, and he has no inflection or charisma in his voice. It's as though he got mad that he wasn't in the rest of the movie, and he didn't want to be relegated to just a voice, so he didn't put much effort into it. That's just a little nitpick, nothing major. 

And you know who's a delight in this movie? Peter Dinklage! Yes, he's in this. Now, I don't watch Game of Thrones, but I loved him in Elf. And he brings so much charm and humor to this movie. His last line delivery is so emotional and raw, that he comes dangerously close to outshining the his three costars. 

Fun side note. I worked with and became pretty good friends with a guy who roomed with Peter Dinklage when he lived in New York jumping from audition to audition. My friend talked about Pete saying that he worked hard, hardly ever slept, and never gave up until he made it. I think that's really cool that he knew someone before he became a super mega star. And I think it's even cooler that a mega star like Peter Dinklage still showed up for an almost thankless role in this movie, but you've got to wonder if even he saw how great it was by reading the script. 

Now this movie has the most ambiguous of endings. It's no mystery, per say, but it just sort of ends before the grand adventure begins. I know there won't be a sequel, but I would have loved to get another 25 minutes where we got to see Mildred and Dixon hunt down the rapist together. 

And if there were a sequel, I'm sure it would be about the aftermath of Mildred and Dixon murdering the rapist in Idaho and his family would demand their arrest, and that movie would be called Three Billboards Outside McCall, Idaho. 

But I'm not going to be bemoan an ambiguous ending — I'll leave that for everyone else. Because this movie was good enough as is. We should be so lucky that a movie this simple, yet great is in existence. 


And now it's time to rate this movie. I think it's pretty clear that I'm going to give this a very high rating. So far I haven't loved, or really even liked any of the movies I've reviewed for Should You Watch It?, but even if I'd been watching movies that I love, this would still rank significantly high. Now keep in mind that as I rank more movies, the scale will grow from 1-10 to 1-20 and so on. But as of now, until I come across something that's even better than this, Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri gets the top slot at first place. I'm rating it a 1. 

You can find me on YouTube, just type in Should You Watch It? The twitter handle is my name Andrew Toy11, Instagram is simply Should You Watch It, and anywhere you listen to podcasts. Find me on any of those platforms and leave your comments and suggestions for what movies or franchises I should do next. Leave a snarky enough comment and I just might give you a shout out. Thanks for listening to Should You Watch It, where I talk about movies of every genre, age, and style. Don't forget to subscribe, like, and I'll see you next time.

My rating is mostly if not completely for Frances McDormand's impeccable performance. This is definitely a thought-provoking movie, but maybe not exactly in a good sense. The more you think about it the more you realize its flaws, plot holes, and the many, many ways in which it could've been better, including but not limited to the shallow, cop-out ending, the boring and generic score, and the much-controversial "redemption narrative" of one of the characters. All anchored by a terrific lead performance.
Funny, sad, gritty, humane.
Hilarious, taut, great performance from the lead.

Martin McDonagh’s latest in his library of scathing black comedies is an absolute triumph on every level. It’s top-tier cast (featuring two Oscar-winning performances, with a third nominated) combine with an outstanding script to bring laughter, tears, gasps, and everything in between. It’s nothing short of a masterpiece.
A wonderful film, even if the ending seemed a little unfulfilling
Trash ending, i hated it !
Best drama 2017! Actors, script and directing superb!

Not what I was expecting, could have been funnier, and not exactly realistic (e.g. not realising the building was on fire when you can feel the heat and see the light). 'You join the club, you're culpable' is a ridiculous notion, and most of the characters were extremely unlikeable. I didn't have sympathy for the main character at all because all she did was hate everybody and everything. Dixon was also a complete scumbag for most of the film, although he had a much better character arc. However, the plot was unique, the acting was great, some of the characters were believable (e.g. Willoughby), and the cinematography, visual effects, and soundtrack were all solid. On the other hand, the ending was disappointing as it cut the film short. Definitely a mixed bag writing wise.

I suggest that if you detest the main female character because of her anger and hate then Frances McDormand's acting and the script has had an impact on you to get that reaction. Any other aspect of the film you react to also speaks volumes of you as a person and your world view to the circumstances and characters of this film which showcases its strength in story telling. Frances, Woody and Sam bring this script alive and there would be many women who can silently relate to Mildred with less actionable retribution. Fantastic script , well acted. Brilliant movie.

Martin McDonagh's Three Billboard Outside Ebbing, Missouri sets its sights on a woman (Frances McDormand) consumed by anguish, suffering, and rage in the aftermath of her daughter's rape and murder.  The film is filled with personal revelations that ultimately lead the characters to varying degrees of redemption, be it the suffering mother, the racist cop (Sam Rockwell), or the terminally ill police chief (Woody Harrelson).  McDonagh again proves himself not only to be a capable director (In Bruges, Seven Psychopaths), but also a brilliant writer, capable of developing memorable characters and creating interesting scenarios that somehow find humor in tragedy and redemption in the seemingly unredeemable.

AMAZING! Very smart and unforeseeable written plot and characters. So many scenes were actually touching on many levels... My girlfriend and I were laughing and crying on several occasions (and it is really hard to make me genuinely cry). After the movie and even the day after we were talking about the movie and how good it was... I guess this is a quite good indicator of a masterpiece.

Incredible. I loved everything about it, from start to finish. There are so many quality, standout characters and I loved all of them, as deeply flawed as they mostly were. The humor never took away from the seriousness of it all either. Just a straight up great movie. Highly recommend it.
Well acted, well directed, and weirdly comedic: it all works in its favor
Definitly watchable. Deals with many topics, but I like the way trying to display the struggle that family members of victims of sexual violence (and murder) need to deal with.

This film has real guts. Dark humour which is excellently well written and in particular the brilliant performances from the leads. Only complaint is that the ending just felt it needed an extra scene however fantastic film.

Overall, Three Billboard Outside Ebbing Missouri is a very entertaining watch with some incredible performances. Frances McDormand rightfully won the Best Actress Oscar that year for playing the lead, Mildrid. While Sam Rockwell's character arc was my personal favourite from the film. The writing is also really good, some funny one liners and some intense ones also when there needs to be. It's not perfect I don't think, maybe that may change with a second viewing, but I thought the pacing was slightly off at times and I was left wanting a little more at some points in the film, but this a good film, one I'll sure to be re-visiting again at some point.

Quote - All this anger, man, it just begets greater anger. - Charlie

Rating - 3.5/5

This is my new favourite movie of all time, and I've watched quite a lot. Maybe the only movie that made me cry, and not just shed a tear but cry in the full meaning of that word (during the suicide scene and the letter reading after it). It is seriously emotional movie but has multiple well placed comedy moments too. 
I like the fact that none of the characters is all good nor bad, they go all the way from "villain" to "hero" (and vice versa) quite a few times, and it is still believable and real nonetheless. So, so real. It's a movie about forgiving and understanding the sole human nature and motives.
I just finished watching it and actually made an account here just so I can submit this and hopefully inspire someone else to watch it (also possibly get the score just a bit up).

One of my favorite movies of all time. A veritable combination of supreme acting and marvelous storytelling.

There's just something about the way characters follow their own trajectories (dare I say, faith?) and yet change, evolve, and make their own decisions along the way that always gets me. It also pulls you in through the sheer force of emotion that everyone can relate to. Not to mention how it sometimes manages to tell a whole story in a few seconds through sublime acting and hints that just 'click'. Hint: breakfast scene.

This movie is very good. It has very few flaws, which is why is gets 4.5/5 stars and not a full 5/5 stars. Even though there are some flaws, the great things about this movie make up for it. For SURE!

RATING: A+  Director: Martin McDonagh
Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri described in one Word probably would be "Masterpiece" cause that is what the film is. The Casting Department did such a superb job with casting the Astonishing Frances Mcdormand and Sam Rockwell who both, with the rest of the cast, were just straight out amazing. And I'm just gonna say it, I thought The Shape of Water was brilliant but I have to say Billboards would've deserved the Best Picture Academy Award more.

This movie had me hooked. She does an amazing job. So does Sam Rockwell. The issues dealt with are contemporary. The only knock i have is the ending. It felt incomplete. I wanted more!

The drama "Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri", which was made in 2017 by Martin McDonagh, tells the story of a woman who has lost her daughter, her husband, faith in justice and her fear of the future. 

Despite the fact that this film's plot is slow-moving, from my point of view, every person who likes dramas will enjoy this film. Because the author has combined the scriptwriter and director in himself and saw the idea as clearly as possible. As a result, we get ground-breaking drama.

It is especially worth noting the play of the actors. You have to watch this film at least for its cast: Frances McDormand, Sam Rockwell and my favourite actor - Woody Harrelson. Two of this 3 won an oscars for this film: for lead acting (Frances McDormand) and supporting acting (Sam Rockwell)

In my opinion, this is a really gripping and thought-provoking film with unexpected ending, which is based on a deep thought: 'Anger breeds anger'.
I'm not sure how we will look back at this movie and it's lack of moralism in a rather dark time, but it still grips the audience in a profound way.
A truly accessible film that tackles a myriad of difficult and confronting topics. You'll experience a vast range of emotions and leave the cinema with a lot to think about.

Despite great acting all throughout I found the movie a bit superficial.  Constantly talking trash and swearing heavily with her own teenager seems to be Frances McDormand's character's personal style in general and not necessarily caused by the tragic death of her daughter.  Besides her anger she doesn't really show us much of herself.  The sudden transformation of one of the cops from a brutal imbecile into a decent person at the end of the movie also didn't ring true.    
I guess I expected more from it.

A terrific modern-day western. Sam Rockwell reminds us he's the best *working* actor alive. An excellent blend of gun-slinging vengeance, bittersweet humor and suspense. However, the lack of a conclusion seriously hurts this film.

I LOVED THIS MOVIE. It is awesome in every single aspect. The acting is beyond amazing... with very well-written characters and veteran actors. The script is incredible as well, managing to craft a plot that mixes black comedy and drama in a spectacular way. A good drama, with good actors, good plot and good old black comedy. What else do you need? Go watch Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri.
Brilliant movie. Had no idea what it was about prior to watching it, but from scene one I was hooked. Weird ending, is there a second movie?
The movie was a little too heavy for my personal tastes, hence the 4 instead of 5 stars.

Phenomenal film. Loved every second.

I've been aware of this film, in name only (didn't know any of the plot etc.), since it came out and have always had a great feeling about it - I just had an inkling it would be great. It isn't, it's much more than that... it's incredible.

The mix between the humour and seriousness is superb, I found myself laughing aloud one moment and then feeling saddened minutes later; that was the case a ridiculous amount of times throughout the 115 minutes.

The premise is pretty mad and filled with coincidences, but I absolutely adore the way it is written and put together onscreen. The cinematography is also beautiful, as is the score. The pacing is fantastic too. All that is without even mentioning the cast, who are outstanding.

What a terrific performance from Frances McDormand, who I always remember from 1998's 'Madeline' - one of the first films I recall watching at a young age. She's utterly brilliant as Mildred, from the first scene to the last. Her co-stars are also top notch, so well cast.

Woody Harrelson (Willoughby) and Sam Rockwell (Dixon) are great in their respective roles, while my personal GOT king Peter Dinklage (James) also appears in a minor part. I liked Caleb Landry Jones (Red), also.

'Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri' is a must-watch!

Probably watched this 3/4 times now and it always throws up something new. In a sense, you can't possibly take in everything ( because of the emotional content ) first time ? There is not one person in the cast who doesn't add to the narrative. By that I mean, everyone is on their "A" game. It's an astonishing, moving piece of cinema that's already a modern classic.

A rare re-watchable Oscar Movie!

THE GOOD
1.Frances McDormand was brilliant. Not sure how much she was acting since she is weird and tough in general but who cares. Clearly deserved that Oscar in 2018.
2. Woody Harrelson has not made a bad movie ever. If he has let me know.
3.Sam Rockwell was great and Oscar worthy (Even though Willam Dafoe should have won for the Florida Project). His characters progression is the highlight of the movie. And his stand out scenes (The Beat Down and Fire) won him that Oscar.
4. The small town vibes. It built a world that elevated the movie and the premise. Small town where everyone knows everyone, country as fuck, and possible corruption looming within the police department really helped this movie.
5.The humor. Many funny moments provided by the three leads. Great balance even though the subject is dark.
6. Caleb Landry Jones as a racist, sexist, or scum bag is undefeated in cinema.
7. Lucas Hedges just cause.

THE BAD
1. The connection to the daughter. She was Murdered and I feel the audience would have connected more with a few more flashbacks with her relationship to Mildred (McDormand).
2.No body in that damn town cares.... Helps the movie but pissed me the fuck off.
I enjoyed watching this movie. It was good.

3 Billboards is ok, not great.  There are lots of recognizable faces here, and some pretty good performances, but alot of the plotline just seemed over the top crazy.  Not in the traditional 'Transformers' sense, but the characters just way overdid it.  McDormand was just over the top angry Rosie the Riveter, and not sympathetic at all.  Rockwell kind of does the racist clown bit and then bad things happen he is now a good guy.  Presto.  I laughed a tiny bit, but to call this a dark comedy would be stretching a LOT.  The slow beginning almost lost me, it picked up in the middle, but the last act just kind of sputtered across the finish line.  Also, it drives me nuts when I can tell the setting is not right - it was far too mountainous and lush for Ebbing to be in Missouri.

I really really enjoyed this film. Initially I really wasnt keen to be honest because the synopsis didnt really sound too appealing to me and I was worried it would be boring. But it surprised me. Excellent characters, excellent acting, good story

Written and Directed by Martin McDonagh. Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri, is a film about a strong female character going against the small-town system where she resides. McDonagh excels at delivering a dark comedy where characters do have consequences for their actions. The story never falls flat and is continuously moving. Comedic timing is executed perfectly throughout the whole cast. All performances are incredibly strong, especially from lead actors in the film—a fun watch, with some twists and turns.

Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri isn't the best movie of 2017, that's still Lady Bird, but this is definitely the second best. This film is fantastic. First off the cast is amazing. Francis McDormand is great in the film. This is the first film I've seen of her's and now I'm even more excited to see Fargo. Woody Harrelson is also great in the film as usual. Sam Rockwell is my favorite part of the film. He acted great and I loved his arc in the film. Because this film gives arcs to people who wouldn't get arcs in other films. It's also extremely unpredictable. If think you know where this is gonna go. you really don't. It's also got one of my favorite things, dark humor. In a millisecond, you'll go from feeling so uncomfortable and scared, to laughing. This is one of the best films of the past few years and you should watch it as soon as possible.

This movie stuck with me, Its one of the movies from those last few years that I just can't stop thinking about. The grey characters and ambiguity of it all have something to say, but not so much that you can't draw your own conclusions.
This movie has a real character twist! It shows that every one has it's reason and no one is just good or just bad. Great acting in a moving story.
Wonderfully acted from top to bottom and deserved all if its award show attention. A black comedy that doesn't overextend its humor and tells a strong, dark story.

This movie is basically just a hodge-podge of tired cliches wrapped in an overly pretentious package. The "idiot cop" trope especially is really tiring. It's hard to see the characters as anything else than basic cardboard cutouts because of this. The only department in which they distinguish themselves is in how unlikeable they all are. I know this is done on purpose but still... that doesn't make the movie enjoyable or interesting. Mildred Hayes is especially grating, to the point you'd almost feel schadenfreude when she doesn't get closure for her daughter's death.
What a waste of talented actors...

This movie seems more like a second or third hand experience of rural America through stereotypes and cliches than an actual one.  Pretty generic and over-the-top like a wannabe Coen Brothers film but not at all on the same level. Also the whole cancer story is cheesy and dumb.  I have no faith in academy awards.

Peliculón, se nota la critica hacia el sistema en general, y esa critica se demuestra con la manera de actuar de los personajes, todos los personajes influyen de buena medida en la historia, incluso aquellos que mas parecen fuera de lugar, logran ser un alivio cómico, me gustaría mencionar especialmente al personaje de Sam Rockwell, alguien abusivo de su poder y que piensa que nadie podría quitárselo, pero cuando se lo quitan se muestra como alguien muy débil en la vida real, que incluso aunque el personaje sea muy amoral te logras sentir mal por el y la actuación de Frances McDormand, de una mujer que haría lo imposible por lograr la justicia, realmente lo que importa en esta película no es como va a terminar, es el cambio que se produce en toda la película, que es lo que les esta pasando a los personajes y como a pesar de tan difícil situación en la que se encuentran logran superarlo

Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri is an incredible film. It is about a mother personally challenges the local authorities to solve her daughter's murder. Frances McDormand and Woody Harrelson give excellent performances. The script is well written. Martin McDonagh did a great job directing this movie. I enjoyed watching this motion picture because of the drama. Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri is a must see.
This movie was listed as a Comedy/Drama but I must have blinked and missed the comedy part.
How did this get a high rating? It was just a weird boring movie.

As a fan of Martin's other films like In Bruges, Seven Psychopaths and the wonderful Six Shooter, Three Billboards did nothing for me in terms of entertainment. Whilst the cast gave wonderful performances, the story itself felt lacking of any true resolve or consequence.

Don't get me wrong, ambiguous endings can be wonderful and thought-provoking, but this movie just left me confused as to why I had just sat through the film.

One of the greatest explorations into morality to ever grace a screen. Simply a masterpiece that must be seen. The average movie doesn't even have half of the twists and turns and ups and downs that this movie has. It's incredible, the writing, acting, casting, directing. It's beyond words.

Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri is the best dark comedy drama independent feature. Frances McDormand was the best actress for portraying Mildred Hayes and Martin McDonagh is fantastic for directing.

Wonderful movie. Powerful and satisfying. However, the ending was very disappointing. They definitely could've justified another half an hour of runtime to make a better ending. I would give the movie, 4.5 stars, but because of the dissatisfying ending, I feel 4 stars is appropriate.

Frances McDormand is without a shadow of a doubt one of the greatest most versatile actors of any generation in film. And for me her portrayal of Mildred Hayes, the mother to a daughter who was abducted, raped and subsequently murdered, has been her finest acting role to date.

Supporting roles from the likes of Sam Rockwell and Woody Harrelson, added to the pathos in this brooding and dark film. They also gave a few lighter moments of humour that came out of nowhere, but not so much as to dilute the mood of the harrowing story.

The only slight weak spot for me was the ending: not wishing to give anything away, but I did feel it jumped the shark a little. But having said that I really could not believe this was a 2 hour film as it seemed more like half-that, and as a consequence I was yearning for more!

A total waste of time, the other reviewers must have watched  something else, the plot was at best lame and non existent, the final outcome was perverse and unjustifiable as much as it was glorifying the case of murder, which was the whole point of the lame plot in the first place where a woman wanted justice for the murder of her daughter.
All of the actors in this film gave a stellar performance. I couldn't imagine a better cast for this film. The end did leave me with some questions, but that may have been the point.
Dark but surprisingly entertaining film. There are plenty of funny moments that break up the depression and the acting is fantastic.

𝐒𝐮𝐦𝐦𝐚𝐫𝐲: Emotional, dramatic, and darkly comedic, 𝘛𝘩𝘳𝘦𝘦 𝘉𝘪𝘭𝘭𝘣𝘰𝘢𝘳𝘥𝘴 follows the unraveling of a passionate, spit-fire mother, Mildred, desperately seeking accountability for the brutal rape and murder of her teenage daughter. Unhappy with the progress of local police investigations, Mildred paints three unmistakable billboards reading, "RAPED WHILE DYING," "STILL NO ARRESTS?" and, "HOW COME, CHIEF WILLOUGHBY?" Tensions quickly rise between Mildred and Chief Willoughby as the pair attempts to navigate their undoubtable chemistry mixed with their professional dissatisfactions with one another.

𝐁𝐫𝐚𝐧𝐝𝐨𝐧'𝐬 𝐭𝐚𝐤𝐞: This is one of my favorite academy recognized films of the decade. The cast is loaded with remarkable actors delivering peak performances, as is evident by the film's Oscar nominations and victories. Consider this: the only reason Harrelson didn't win Best Supporting Actor is because his co-star Rockwell won the award for his performance in the same movie. McDormand waltzed into a Best Actress victory with an on-screen presence that is incontestably at the highest level of acting. In my opinion this was one of the biggest Best Picture snubs in Oscars history due to an academy nod at the creative, niche (and, in my opinion, entirely overrated) film 𝘛𝘩𝘦 𝘚𝘩𝘢𝘱𝘦 𝘰𝘧 𝘞𝘢𝘵𝘦𝘳. It's a real shame how few people recognize . While I try to recommend films available for streaming on major platforms, this one is absolutely worth the $3.99

"Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri" is a phenomenal film. It is able to convey the emotions it wants you to feel very effectively and the characters are compelling. Each character in this film has their own troubles and they come together in great fashion. The acting by Frances McDormand, Sam Rockwell, and Woody Harrelson is top-notch. McDormand and Rockwell both received Oscars for their performances while Harrelson was nominated. These characters take this film's compelling story and sell it tactfully and beautifully. The mastery of the directing and cinematography makes for a very gripping motion picture. Overall, the only qualm I can nitpick with this film is the unsatisfying ending. The intensity and drama of the entire film leads us down a path towards what could be an amazingly satisfying ending, to only leave us wanting a few minutes more. However, with that being stated, the ending is left open enough for us, as the audience, to create our own ending for the film. This could have been done in a better fashion than it was, but other than this qualm, this film is fantastic. Overall, I give this film a 9/10 for its compelling story, acting, and directing.
Amazing movie, I was surprised at first that I enjoyed it. But it's a great movie even worth rewatching.
A tremendously good movie, one of the best I've seen
All the Oscars were well earned here, nominations too. I gave The Shape Of Water a 10/10 and I still feel that this one should have won Best Picture over it. 10/10.

This movie blows my mind away. Each and every character has depth and you can see them all evolve throughout the movie. There is also foreshadow strewn throughout the movie that by the end you feel thoroughly satisfied. It is a must-see movie!

There are very few pictures that can pull off being traumatic, suspenseful, moving and funny. A brilliant screenplay combined with stellar  performances by McDormand and Rockwell make this film a must see.

This critically acclaimed black comedy-drama, written and directed by Martin McDonagh, an Irish-British playwright, is as inauthentic about rural America as "American Beauty" is about suburbia. Frances McDormand is Mildred Hayes, a Missouri woman who rents three billboards to call attention to the local police and the town for the unsolved rape and murder of her daughter. Woody Harrelson is the police chief and target of her wrath. Sam Rockwell is a racist police officer with a penchant for brutality. McDonagh presents the material as a black comedy, but there are almost no laughs here and the movie comes across as callous and glib. McDormand said she based her performance on John Wayne, but she's playing a single-minded, humorless Wayne mixed with a vindictive Charles Bronson. Mildred acts smugly in a way that really made me resent the contempt the filmmakers show for the audience. The redemption of Rockwell rings false and the fate of Harrelson is melodramatic. Of the three main actors, only Harrelson is convincingly able to bring out his character's humanity. Won Oscars for Best Actress (Frances McDormand), Supporting Actor (Sam Rockwell). With Abbie Cornish, John Hawkes, Peter Dinklage.
Excellent movie! Performances from Woody Harrelson and Frances Mcdormand were fantastic. I used to discount Woody to some degree, not anymore......he is a fantastic actor.
Wow, this movie left me speechless. Grief, guilt, anger, hope, redemption and love, all the emotions were beautifully written and displayed by an amazing script, direction and excellent performances.
McDonaghs, both of them, should stick to Ireland when writing stories. Their American characters are acting in very un-American ways and that seriously hurts the movie's believability.
Compelling story with excellent cast and performances.  Surprisingly funny.
A near perfect black comedy. Frances McDormand gives her best performance since Fargo, showing she is one of the best actresses of her time.

The characters were all over the place.  Erratic direction, with one inconsistent action after another leading to most of the characters being barely tolerable. The only likeable character in the entire movie was Dixon towards the end, which makes the struggles of the rest of them irrelevant. Also the movie feels half completed and the ending was extremely lazy. It would have been a 3 star movie but since it is just half of it, it's 2 stars. Also Frances Mcdormand acts superbly but that's because of her insane behaviour and her character's actions which are not coherent with the overall direction so I'm not sure about the Oscar.

WARNING: There WILL be spoilers in this review. You've been warned.

First off, despite the 3.5 stars, this was a very good movie. It wasn't boring, self serving or pointless. The characters were well written, the actors were superb and the performances Oscar worthy.

Where it loses me a bit is that, at the end of the film, the only thing those 3 billboards did was aggravate the police and get 2 people seriously injured. If you came into the movie wanting there to be police corruption in the murder of the girl, there was none. If you came into the film hoping the killer would be caught because of the billboards, you'll be disappointed. The police aren't what they seem and the main "bad" guy is a reckless drunkard cop with a serious superiority complex. Even Woody Harrelsen's character, the Sheriff isn't a crooked cop.

So in the end you find yourself asking yourself who was the antagonist in this film? Who do you root for? For a film about 3 billboards, I was hoping they would have gotten some answers. Perhaps them being for the most part ineffective was the point of them in the main plot - that sometimes murders take time to solve, and as hurt and desperate you may become, sometimes the police did everything they could do. Sometimes the police aren't the bad guys.

Overall, if you can put the billboards aside, as they start the plot moving but become more ineffective as the film progresses, there is enough emotion, gripping dialogue and tension to easily make this one of the better films of this nature released in the last few years. It doesn't rely on a big budget and special effects to drive it forward - the performances are enough to keep you hooked.

I think this is very much an example of what cinema was made for. Three Billboards is excellent. It's a film much like the, often focused on, tied back undercut of Frances McDormand's hair; it very much presents two diametrically opposed things at once, one on top, one underneath and it lets us feel the way we want about them. Frances' Mildred may very well have been crazy before her daughter was killed, we don't know as we're mercifully and brilliantly dropped in months into her grieving process. People don't generally write slice of life films like this unless they're true stories, which intensifies the proof of skill writer/director Martin McDonagh has with writing nuanced, balanced, flawed characters. He manages, from his background writing plays, to not waste a single scene, there is not one moment in this film that doesn't bleed into another at some point and every moment gives weight to the next in the kind of suspense, surprise and momentum that other films just dream of having. The film uses its small microcosm of Ebbing, Missouri, and it's small incomplete story, to subvert film cliches effortlessly. There's a moment where Woody Harrelson coughs blood in the middle of a tough interrogation scene and the artificiality of his demeanour and that moment is just killed dead; his face shocked like a little boy's, his subject actually instantly taking pity on him. I've seen this in real life, I've never seen a moment like this in film, a construct built on artificiality, to use that construct to break it, just to show how human these human-like artifices are, is as close to magic as cinema gets. What am I talking about? I mean, I know, do you? And if you do, can you explain it to the next guy, cos I can't.

This is one of those films that has social commentary and a message but still brings an enjoyable narrative and memorable characters, something that I think can be very rare. But 3 Billboards, in a similar fashion to Farhadi's A Separation or The Salesmen, sides with all of them, giving a hopeful tone that may be just what will save this movie from falling into irrelevancy.

I doubt the writer has ever even been there. Still, his contempt was unmistakable.

Three billboards Outside Ebbing Missouri is from my point of view an amazing movie that all people have to watch in one point of their life. The characters are really well done, some of them are too easy to hate but at the same time you feel shame and even empathy for them, they are not just predictable characters that you know how they are going to end, instead you feel like they really exist because unfortunately this difficult situation could happen in real life. And finally I love this movie for the performance of the protagonist, she reach what the movie needed, she showed a clear and strong case of female empowerement, because whichever way you see the situation about the protagonist she was in disadvantage but she was full of anger and frustration so the only thing she was looking for was to do visible the negative position in what the women of her town find themselfs.

Have you ever think about how would you feel if you lose someone you love so much, like a daughter or son, no? well the tragically story of Mildred Hayes and her daughter would make you realize how important is to live in the moment an enjoy all the experiences that life could give you. Francis McDormand did such a wonderful job as Mildred Hayes (not for nothing she won an Oscar and a Golden Globe for best actress) , mother of which daughter was raped and killed by an evil man, I loved the way of how she actually understood the true feeling of what it means to lose someone so important in your life, I don't believe that it was false or very simulated cause she acted like a normal people, use the right vocabulary to express the anger and desperation, even her behavior make me feel identify. During the movie I laughed hard and often, and then I cried, and wince, and laughed again all almost the same time.
From my point of view, the dialogue and the screenplay were amazing, well connected to the space, to the characters in fact to the story itself. I am a hundred percent sure that this movie can make you realize if you are doing something wrong with your loved ones, if you are not taking care of yourself enough, even if you are wasting your time and you are not enjoying the life.
The only think I don't like so much was the name, in my perspective it's a little cliché and literal, however if you see it for first time it's pretty obvious and maybe ingenious, but can make you feel stupid. 
I send my congratulations to the directors, to the producer, the writers all the team in general for do an excellent work and show us a little part of how real life works and how people suffers.

Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri is a film directed by Martin McDonagh known for other great films like Seven Psychopaths and In Brudges. The film came out on 2016 and has been regarded as a cult classic ever since. It tells the story of Mildred, a mother of two whose daughter had been murdered and raped; as there is a lack of interest from the local police on the murder of her daughter she decides to take justice in her own hands and push the police to restart the investigation in the form of three billboards with messages against the chief of the town. Little does she know that everything will go off the rails from there….
The movie on itself is a pretty worthwhile experience, there is plenty of good acting, specially from the main leads played by Frances McDormand (in probably her best performance to date) and Sam Rockwell. Their characters, despite having differences on their perception of justice, manage to deliver a solid and believable hate relationship that evolves in such a natural scheme that you find yourself astonished on how almost perfectly everything plays out for them at the end of the film.
There is always a feeling of unpredictability to it, you never know where the story is going to go, you could certainly say that most of the movie is composed of plot-twists but it is mind-blowing to know that they don't feel forced at any moment as the story progresses with a pretty light pace without feeling over-stuffed during its whole runtime.
The technical aspects are breathtaking, McDonagh proves to be a masterful director once again with a familiar story that takes a bizarre approach to its subject matter. There is plenty to enjoy from masterful directing to a beautiful soundtrack composed of country and classic music that turns Three Billboards into a remarkable craft.
Motherhood, vengeance, redemption and regret are only a handful of the themes touched in Three Billboards. The emotional parts hit you hard most of the time because everything about it feels so authentic, it is an authentic work of passion.
Conclusion: Three Billboards is probably the best movie to come out on 2017 and its impact will remain as one of the most heartbreaking black comedies of the decade, the conflict feels real and the characters, the heart of the film, make it worth a watch.

On the other hand, I was not all that impressed.  I understand the motivation of McDormand's character Mildred Hayes.  She is distraught and angry over the brutal murder of her daughter and is angry that her killer or killers have not been brought to justice.  When people get into situations as these they tend to loose all civility and act erratically.  I would not mind that so much if the people in Ebbing were not so intently awful.  I also don't get how a police officer can damage property and throw people out of windows with dozens of people witnessing the event and the police officer is not held accountable for it in any way.  Also Mildred can commit arson and get away with it.  It just could not buy it try as I may.  In the end, I think the movie is well made and acted, but rather overrated.

Frances McDormand and Woody Harrelson give great performances and the screenplay contains some real gems which are the main reasons why you should watch this film. Mildred Hayes, Frances McDormand, has grown increasingly frustrated over the lack of progress in the investigation of the rape and murder of her daughter Angela. She places three billboards emblazoned with accusatory statements in a field leading into their town and comes into conflict with the town's reasonable police chief William Willoughby, Woody Harrelson, who is dying of cancer. Volatile, racist Officer Jason Dixon, Sam Rockwell, assaults the homosexual man who allowed Mildred to place the billboards but when tragic circumstances lead to the loss of an important figure Mildred and Dixon will have to unite.

At the beginning of the film it was easy to empathize with the lead character's anger and righteous indignation but the introduction of the flawed but sympathetic Willoughby made the film more layered. We see him as a family man and I fully expected him to be the rapist and killer based on this portrayal but when a shocking twist of another nature occurs I felt quite emotional. Harrelson is a great actor, as shown by The People vs. Larry Flynt (1996) and his brief role in The Thin Red Line (1998), and here he is likable and affable while still seeming like a jaded police chief. The scenes in which he interacts with his family felt mawkish but this was mainly McDonagh's direction and the character serves as a nice counterbalance to the main character.

McDormand is very good in her role as an angry, aggrieved woman but I wanted to see some moments of her relenting or being slightly less than extremely angry. The main character journey in the film is that of Dixon as we see his efforts to track down Angela's murderer become more concerted after he survives a raging fire. This development could work in a film that feels less sentimental but the treatment of his character initially, as a comical racist, makes it strange when we are meant to emotionally invest in his character changing. Obviously he faced serious physical damage but we never see any mental repercussions for his assault of a gay man and when they are placed together in the hospital I did not pity him. Although the final scene is entertaining and suggests that Mildred will be fulfilled I didn't think it should have been as cut and dry as it was when we are meant to see him through new eyes.

McDonagh's direction is assured and the film is paced well despite most scenes ending with Mildred physically abusing someone. The straightforward attitude that McDonagh takes to filmmaking is positive in this day and age where every filmmaker seems as though they are trying to be a young Christopher Nolan and uses non-linear storytelling. The colors of the film are fresh and vibrant with red being the dominant color and the image of the three billboards standing out starkly against the greens of the field. The score didn't have much impact when considering the fact that it received a Best Original Score Academy Award nomination but it's better to be irrelevant than extremely present and awful like in River's Edge (1986).

I can't even begin to describe the depths to which I hated this film - mostly because it was almost unanimously salivated upon by the mainstream of salaried media critics who couldn't have possibly been more automatic in their cultural gullibility.

What you get in this albeit competently executed film (the acting is alright, the cinematography is sufficient), is a British playwright rummaging around American culture, trying to position himself as a purveyor of rural culture studies, then pulling the old trick of having absolutely nothing to say about it.  Seen by his gullible cultural elitist peers in media, this is an avant-garde move, sophisticated and edgy.  To normal people, it's a huge bore.  Speaking for myself, and estimating the reactions of sane people, we couldn't care less about a single character conjured up for this movie that's about nothing at all.  Frances McDormand has clearly gotten the aristocratic keys to the kingdom, and cannot do wrong:  critics have always fawned over every flinch she ever made, probably built on the good will of her public virtue-signalling, so there you have it.  Peter Dinklage is just thrown into this casting mix for a minor part, always lusting for the unlikely target of Frances, because...hey, look at him?  How woke is that?  And the cancerous sergeant's wife is just there to be pleasantly supportive, then vilified, and never relevant.  There is tone-deaf melodrama, virtue signalling, wink-wink irony, and operatic underscore dumped onto two spots, but absolutely nothing of value in this film (besides the currency of proclaiming you "get it" when there's nothing to get besides popularity).

It's one thing when major critics sell their souls and fawn over mainstream tentpole ultra-violent superhero movies.  Of course they have to, staying on payroll.  But when they drool on pretentiously banal drivel like this, it's a sign of creepy corruption in media.  Don't trust them, and don't read them.  Newspapers and magazines are dying off anyway.

As a political statement about hot-button issues like racism and sexism, Martin McDonagh’s “Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri” doesn’t really work, which is fine because the filmmaker has other intentions. Nor is this a film that wishes to reside in the viewer’s good graces; it’s as ornery, unforgiving, strict and wily as its heroine, Mildred. Brilliantly played by Frances McDormand, Mildred is the straw that stirs the rage-filled drink McDonagh serves the audience. Her revenge-driven quest for justice is the catalyst for all manner of mischief and carnage, and while she’s ostensibly the film’s protagonist, her avenging angel has far too much devil in her to be above reproach. You want to root for her, but she often makes you sorry you did. The film pulls you in and doesn’t let go until the very end. Highly satisfying movie.

This felt like another emotional roller coaster with great emotional value and great humor and funny jokes. The actors where as perfect as perfect gets. The emotional scenes where just simply a masterpiece and they delivered the feelings of sorrow, love, vengeance and anger in such a meaningful and artistic way. The director's style and choice in cinematography is simply something Iv'e never seen before. Fresh and very well executed. The movie is such an entertaining piece and it keep the tension high all the way through with it's amazing unforeseen events and turns that it depicts the struggle of real life perfectly. The shadiness and lies and every single detail was outstandingly executed. The characters are just so perfectly written and acted and such complex personalities with profound moral codes that it is hard to even start to comprehend yet still believable, because it strongly reflects the reality to much. The emotional power this movie has is just amazing. The music also helped the impeccable immersion and tension. The situations our main characters are presented with and interacting with each other are often grotesque. But the humor and funny situations are very well delivered as well. I honestly had gags in one minute and tears in my eyes the other minute. It's literally like a lifeline of emotional overwhelming project. 
Overall it's an amazing movie which it's a must watch if you can stomach the drama genre. It was always a 10/10 masterpiece but the conclusion and ending was a bit lack luster which cut right before the apex of the events. None the less the message is clear and strong visiting true problems in the world. AMAZING!!!!

Three Billboards has some great moments. Overall I would say the timing is off with most of the humor however. Seemed like McDonagh was too accustomed to writing/directing for the stage. The film didn't come close to the magic of In Bruges but it is enjoyable. Will watch it again with boxxy software app.
Unforgettable performance from it's veteran cast, Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri sets the tone to both dark comedy and crime drama films.

seriously one of the best movies I've ever seen ever

Stunning acting from a superlative cast. Just shows what can be done with a simple setting, minimal special effects (okay, the explosion), and just a spectacular script.
