3.5 out of 5 stars
A typically well put together film from end-to-end that checks off all boxes required to be an Oscar contender.  Fine script.  Solid performances.  Appealing shot making.  While I was thoroughly invested in the movie while watching it, there was nothing that stood out that would entice me to return to it again in the future.
One of the best movies I have ever seen.

I'm not quite sure how to rate or assess this film.  It has a rather bizarre take on human behavior, trying ultimately to convince us that love and forgiveness are the most important human emotions, but along the way showing us mostly brutal and stupid human beings engaged in the most outrageous behavior with the most inexplicable lack of consequences much of the time.  There are numerous issues of logical inconsistency or contrived situations that play out in ways that make little sense, not just that they are unexpected but that they are loony and abhorrent.  Frances McDormand is an excellent actress, but here she plays a character who is unconvincing as a bereaved mother who, in her grief over the loss of her daughter, is not just righteously angry but downright mean and undeserving of our sympathy the more we learn about the investigation into that murder.  Woody Harrelson plays a sheriff who is the target of McDormand's character as she faults him for failing to find her daughter's killer, but the film wants us to see the sheriff as a very decent guy who is the loving core of the film. Yet he can't even discipline his racist, lazy officer who runs amok much of the time.  Sam Rockwell was given awards for his portrayal of that rogue cop, played in a way that is more freakish and hateful than sympathetic.  I don't consider this a bravura performance at all; it's more of an oddball play for dark humor that just doesn't work well.  The final scenes are more unbelievable than redeeming in a film that can't manage to make enough sense.

Terrible movie attempting to be real, but just fails hard!   Dialogue in the movie is probably the worst part about the entire movie.  Also a lot of stupid illogical plot failures that take away from the movie, like the cop throwing people out the window in front of the new chief and nothing happens to the cop???  That's a really hard fail in the attempt to try and be realistic movie.

I really wanted to like this movie.  But it was absolutely horrible.  No character in the film acts like any real human would.  The only character with anything close to feeling real kills himself halfway through as if he could not stand to be in this anymore.  Cussing in movies doesn't bother me but it is so prevalent in this film (to the point where the police chief cusses throughout a discussion with his two very young daughters in what is supposed to be  a happy scene) it brought me out of the movie several times thinking that is not how people talk.  Also it seems as if the Irishman who wrote the story stereotyped southerners.  Rednecks the last group it is politcally correct to make fun of. And what is with the enormous age differences in the chief and his wife and the ex and his girlfriend?

Sam Rockwell has never done better. His portrayal of a violent mama's boy with a badge and gun is downright scary. Frances McDormand (Fargo) does what she does best any brings to life a driven woman who while no saint is determined to tell the world that sometimes even if people do their best, often it's not good enough. Worthy of every accolade.
I enjoyed this.  Well written and entertaining which is what a movie should be.  Francis did a great job but I'm not sure why Woody was nominated.  I recommend this movie.

The most overrated film this decade. Ridiculous storyline with some mixed acting. The leading lady certainly didn't deserve her Oscar; I can only presume the film company paid for it. Borderline watchable; a very poor film indeed. Thoroughly disappointing.

Creates some interesting character arcs that I don't agree with, but turned out to be my favorite film of the year. Fantastic performances all around. Definitely hard to watch, but worth watching nonetheless.

If you are making a movie about an unsolved murder, you don't need to add any "topical" narrative that white guys harass black people. You don't need to hammer in how bad someone is with the false narrative currently trending, i.e. that cops are racist and like to torture and hunt black people. Just the same old stereotype of "southern" cops being bad cops.

There were just so many things that I wasn't buying, i.e. wasn't believable. The constant harassment of Sam Rockwell of Caleb Landry Jones, like in the middle of the street, or in the bar. Just didn't buy it would ever happen.

Like the priest scene. Never would happen. Only in fantasy writing land.

Like the dentist was gonna use torturous methods against Frances. None of this would EVER happen. Just made no sense and poorly written.

This movie was one not believable scene after the other. For example, the Police chief coughing up blood and spitting it in Frances face. Never would have happened.

Writers: STOP WRITING DIALOGUE AND SCENARIOS that never would happen.

The one scene that actually felt real, was the daughter scene needing the car and they started arguing about it. But to go to another scene that would NEVER happen. Ex-husband throws over the table and tries to strangle Frances, then the son take knife to ex, and then the new girl (way too young) makes a "comedic" entrance and reacts totally in a way no one would ever react.

Unfortunately, it was soooo painful to watch, but I guess with so many worse movies out, the below mediocre films get a lot of praise.
NOT GREAT   DUMB AT TIMES

It started with an interesting premise but went downhill from there.  A mother cannot get over her daughter's horrible death and the fact that the rapist was never caught.  Hoping to nudge the Sheriff into action, she puts up 3 billboards outside of town.  Frances McDermond thought she was too old for the role and she was.  She is 60 and could easily play 70 but not 50.
There is only one marginally believable and likable character in the movie and he kills himself.  By this time, I was thinking of joining him.  The cast of police officers contained not one memorable character.  The much touted bad guy cop who is somehow reformed by a letter from the dead sheriff and getting badly burned just never becomes real to me.
The Mother does insane things ending with firebombing the police station.  Why they chose to insert a midget for a cringeworthy scene is never explained.
I kept watching hoping for some sort of resolution but it never comes leaving one of those ambiguous endings that critics seem to love but people hate.
THIS MOVIE IS AMAZINGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGG
Wonderful movie.  Outstanding cast performances, especially for Oscar winners Frances McDormand and supporting actor, Sam Rockwell.  Loved the writing. Winner in my book.
leaves ya hanging...

Dixon!

Holy shit, what a genuinely good movie. I love it when an experience is this well put together. Left me feeling incredibly satisfied about nearly everything.

I was invested in every scene, in every character. I adored the depth and humanity that was written into everyone in this story. All the main actors, and even some of the minor ones, really gave it their all. Solid, beautiful performances all around. We need more characters like these. Characters that feel human, that are whole and complex beings.

The story pulled me in from the get-go. It didn't waste any time, every moment in this movie felt right and in its place, a part of a larger complete whole. The tonal shifts felt amazing and human. The comedy was done just right, the drama was done just right, the mix in between was great and felt natural. I'm actually really satisfied by how well all these tones meshes together here. Shows they did a good job. The story also shifts and progresses in such an engaging way, but steers clear of an ending that's tied up too well. It's so confident in what it aims to achieve. You could see that it's a project that was done after the people involved were completely satisfied with what they had. It looks like a great passion project.

The cinematography was unexpectedly gorgeous, yet subtle. The songs complimented the movie well. The visuals were all very crisp and alive. The editing helped tie this movie together as well as it ended up. No complaints here. Loved it.

Sam Rockwell better win that damn supporting actor Oscar.

Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri is not for the faint of heart. Francis McDormand and her stellar supporting cast are a flawless bunch who complete this melancholic, socially aware and at times darkly comic drama that explores human relationships and tragedy.

A little overrated, perhaps, but it earns its Oscars. Good shifts by McDormand and Harrelson, but Sam Rockwell's scenery-chewing was a bit too much for me. A nice mix of drama and black comedy, with a well-judged ending.
powerful & deeply moving. however, did not enjoy the ending scene
Love, love, loved it!
What a predictable story. Nothing special at all. Only good thing about the movie is the acting from all the actors. If not because of them it will not even be worth the average score.

Is it well done? Yes. Absolutely. Is it compelling? I watched every minute of it. Did I enjoy the experience? Nope. This is a film that seeks to tell me something I know. The world is brutal and unfair. Our choices define us. And then it leaves the definition up to the viewer. Artistically bold? Not really. There are so many films that say this same thing and yet find humor and character.
I will be thinking about these characters for some time to come!
So much more better than the winner!
So good & really touched on the real pain of suffering something like that!
Loved it. Well made, great script, excellent characters with a lot of quirks but also very realistic. A significant amount of comedy, despite the dark subject matter. Would highly recommend.

This has to be the worst film I have seen since Requiem for a Dream.  Everything about this movie felt like a cartoon....totally unrealistic situations, premises and characters.  Completely blatant debasing of the human condition on every level.  The fact that this mindless trash is adored by a huge percentage of reviewers is bleak for this planet.

Director Martin McDonagh pulls off a good mix of drama and humour, in this touching story about a woman trying to find justice for the rape and murder of her daughter, touching and changing the lives of those around her, learning a few lessons about prejudice along the way.

Great movie, amazing performances (Frances McDormand is incredibly talented, she is by far one of the finest actresses of all times). I've got to be honest, some of the scenes are quite "hard" to watch, for they are extremely moving, still it remains enjoyble and it also makes you laugh. In one word: brilliant.

Lovedddd this movie. Was rooting for it to win Best Picture, but I'll take the Best Actress for Frances McDormand and Best Supporting Actor for Sam Rockwell instead. Sad storyline, but Frances really pulls through on this film, as she always does. Very serious movie, but laughs are thrown in there too.

Three billboards deals with some serious subject matter and kudos to it for that (I know of a similar incident that happened in Massachusetts a few years back).  But the film just isnt up to the task of  dealing with its grim subject matter.  I could be wrong but one would think the rape and murder would leave a small town like Ebbing shattered for years after.  And likewise the police department would not be brushing aside the event as unsolvable but instead doing all they could to not leave a black mark on their record.  But for some reason in this movie the Sherrif and his staff seem only mildly annoyed about the crime that happened less than a year before.  And the townspeople strangely turn on the mother of the victim when she has the billboards put up.  So right off the bat i thought the film was very hard to believe . Likewise when it tries to suddenly turn into a quirky colorful comedy it left me wondering...wait wasnt this a film about a rape and murder?  No doubt its a difficult task to get a story rolling after such a  horrific crime its starts with but that still doesnt excuse the film.  It still needs to tell a reasonably believe able story.  And then we get that the sherriff has terminal cancer.  I mean I normally dont get into understated films but this one goes in the other direction.  Its like it was made by Marvel comics.    The story goes on from there with more broad stroke comical turns in the story (bad cop turns into good cop etc.)   At least one scene -where one cop reads a poignant letter unaware that flames are building around him-is apparently unintentionally funny.  And Frances McDormand doesnt add much depth to her role.  She just glares coldly and angrily.    I dont know.  Maybe this film was supposed to work as a metaphor?  Maybe i am just missing something.     But I was really expecting something here like No Country for Old Men.  Something gritty with character and layers of meaning.  Didnt get any of that here,.

I'm sincerely disappointed in this movie. 

In the scene where Mildred was chastising the priest for being compellable in the crimes associated with the priesthood because he had "joined the gang" I got really excited because I thought that the messaging was pointing to a really specific place. I thought that the movie was going to make a statement about Willoughby and how he was beloved in the small town because overall he was a nice man and a good person but yet he was also compellable in the crimes associated with his gang (a.ka. the police). At some point Willoughby said something to the effect of "oh if I didn't hire racists I wouldn't have any officers" which reads as a lazy generalization on the part of his character to not do better due diligence on the hiring in his force. So, sure he's a nice guy... but he's compellable so he's actually not the hero the town is making him out to be.  

Furthermore I though the movie was going to demonstrate the social backlash of speaking up when you witness racism or calling the police out when they're not doing their jobs properly. Mildred's son demonstrated how he would prefer to remain socially compliant over outspoken because of the social pressure to conform around him whereas Mildred felt increasing pressure to fall into the social norms and behaviors of her small town. 

I was really impressed with the movie up until none of this above actually happened. What did end up happening was that the racist cop got some strange, confusing redemption arc and became the main focal point of the movie that we were expected to sympathize with. 

What a complete disappointment

I love that Oscar season bring us some true, well-crafted gems that mix a considerable amount of dare with a fresh voice that is fully aware of his influences. I do think Oscars do tend to rely on simpler movies that are way more straight-forward and oscar-baity, but every year there are some captivating and out of the blue picks. Three Billboards stands out as a fully realized film with one of the strongest screenplays of the year which connects with a watchful director that works with his actors to develop characters in a way that feels overarching to us. And although Sam Rockwell and Woody Harrelson's performances are levelled representing what a supporting actor should be all about, Frances McDormand's takes the cake. Her character is one of the most gratifying and enrapturing female character of recent memory, with a woman whose emotions are played out through subtle movements, body posture and a foul mouth that makes her entirely genuine. It's enthralling to watch as Mildred deals internally with her anger and how she decides to make her actions the continuation of the fire we see in her eyes. That goes along perfectly with the movie's greatest theme: the duality of anger. We start to be fondly aware of anger, it's our way of laughing and connecting to her. Then, the movie realizes that anger is not the answer but acknowledges its importance in the process of grief. And it's in this town that is a character by itself where Mildred furthers her anger and interacts with the police force who seems ineffective. The film faultlessly develops anger throughout it and balances with a dark sense of humour, finding wit in grim situations and the playfulness of our condition as humans that don't really understand how to deal with each other. It understands that anger is inherently connected with laughter, as they fought for attention like Inside Out. Ultimately, it's the reminder that the solution in our pain isn't in the world around us and that, nonetheless, we have to make it suffer before we're at peace with ourselves

One of the exceptional films that managers to capture the perplex frame of a crime, the grief surrounding it and the ardent desire of revenge. A unique portrayal of a vindicative, strong and completely broken mother who chooses to grasp the sharp edges and form the answer to the unsolved rape and murder case through blood and tears directed by Martin McDonagh. 

Nevertheless, the contradictory fight for revenge, or else justice, bounces back upon her shoulders as a rope of distraught reputation of her son, public scandals and agonizing loathings in town. The portrayal of the mother by Frances McDormand is indeed phenomenal. As its reflected in her sincere glance, an unspoken code of motherhood is revealed in her caring yet hidden. The fragility and loss of a lonely individual slips out rarely, nevertheless leaving a clear mark of pathos and empathy in the audience. 

The bleak, sand, grey shades of the image only reinforce the idea of fading people in a fading, decaying town. «Three Billboards» de-romanticizes the idea of a maudlin tragedy which has become increasingly popular nowadays in cinematography, capturing the vivid good versus evil cases of sacrifice, suicide and sorrow. The mature approach that reveals the darkest, sharpest edges and the complexity of conflict over human emotions, relationships and actions. 

The film may reveal footsteps of long-gone humanity and faith in it to one part of the audience, whereas the other will only recognize a disappointing feature of egoism, cruelty and giving up. The sincerity and flawed nature of the characters makes the story reflect reality, a believable, painful and anarchic case of the consequences, not the crime. «Three Billboards» leaves you in an inexorable search for human values, morality and humanity.

The whole thing misfires completely - racist, crude, insipid, 100% UNREALISTIC  

I don't know where to begin with this criticism. After all the hype it was very disappointing. 

The entire cast - with the surprising exception of Weed aficionado Woody Harleson - are miscast, Frances McDormand included. It is like they were staging the production with an under attended drama group, so they had to shoehorn various unsuitable people into the roles. 

The film is uniquely broad in its racism. Of course the first type is blatant against the nasty white man, this will be why it did so well at the BAFTAs etc, with the film embodying a gloriously unsubtle yet well established paradigm that all white male cops in the South are just racists or restrained-racists. Secondly, we have the insipid racism - clearly lost on the good people at BAFTA - towards the back people. This is demonstrated by McDonagh's failure to allow them any major roles or much screen time bar the short appearance of the new black chief of police. The black peoples live as adjuncts to the benevolent good white people. It is really like a film set in pre-Revolutionary times where their only hope is for a white person to be nice or take an interest. It was infuriating. Oh and throw into the mix a small person or 'midget' in the form of Peter Dinklage so what does McDonagh do... include him as a normal person? Or make a spectacle out of him... you guess. 

This culminates in McDormand and Rockewell throwing about the N-word randomly. This is a dicey thing for any actor to do, and here, it just feels forced; as though McDonagh has jammed it in to generate some shock laughs. Well congratulations Martin, you wrote down a naughty word. For a film that takes itself so seriously on racism and has tried to stand as a virtuous tome for the oppressed the nonchalant approach to it feels fake as hell. 

The main issue with the film is the entire premise: A young blonde woman/girl (she is 18 at the time of the crime) is gang raped, murdered then severely burned or murdered by the incineration itself, and seven months later, the mother applies greater pressure to the Police Department of the local town to spend more time finding the unapprehended perpetrators, while the townsfolk take against the mother for trying to get the cops to do their job... Let me ask you, you live in a sleepy small town in MO where a girl has been gang raped, murdered and her body largely destroyed by a fire. Would you A) want the police to get their act together and  do everything within their power to find the rapists/killers EVEN IF THIS TAKES DECADES, (WHILE YOUR TOWN SLOWLY RECOVERS FROM THIS DEVASTATING OCCURRENCE!) or B) express universal displeasure at the mother and her pleas for greater attention to be given to the crime, and side with the ineffectual police force, and just forget about the un-apprehended rapists/killers... to the point that you assault the mother and vandalise property!

Moreover McDormand's surrounding family seem to have been afflicted by the same blasé attitude to this egregious crime on their sister/daughter. The estranged husband is much more interested in his new and unbelievably young girlfriend while the son is unhappy about it all, because 'some guys on the team' have been giving him hassle  about the fuss McDormand is now making. This is so bizarre!!! 

Woody Harleson is good as the chief of local police, he brings a warmth to the role. But his B story involving him having cancer and killing himself by a gunshot wound to the head is bizarre. The guy is healthy enough to romp about with his (again) strangely young and bizarrely accented New Zealander wife, but then after leaving her on the sofa in their living room he nips of to write seemingly enumerate Last Letters, then pop up to his barn and kill himself... oh with just enough time to let his horses out of their stable. No good reason, perhaps some metaphor about freedom but again it just seems weird. Him having cancer and dying is a strange counterpoint to the narrative of the young girl's rape and murder, one I do not get the point of. Aside it's place in the story, McDonagh cannot know much about cancer and how it affects people. 

Our Best Supporting Actor winner is fine in the role but there is little depth to it and again he seems miscast, i.e. far too old to be playing a young cop. He beats up black people, he uses pejoratives, he's seemingly corrupt but also of course stupid and only able to live with his old Red-Necky mother. Cheer's Martin, lets all set about and have some good ole Red Neck bashing in this really sophisticated and nuanced way! People have a problem with his conversion to good cop, (the incident is again bizarre as he is seemingly oblivious to the roaring fire, started by multiple petrol bombs, that grows and surrounds him) which is actually one of the more believable parts of this movie for me. He gets a letter from his dead friend finally praising him as well giving him some stern advice, if anything would make a person change, a correspondence like that would.  But his whole story-arch is just so one dimensional, its like 'The Hero's Journey' for complete beginners, not Academy Award Nominees/Winners! It is so contrived and false I just cannot entertain it.  Continuing the unbelievable theme; Rockwell seriously injures a guy for no legal reason, he almost kills the man in broad daylight in the middle of the town, but that goes unchallenged! and he is only reprimanded for being disrespectful to the new police chief! Again, as with the subject of cancer, it is like McDonagh has no concept of violence or its ramifications other than what he knows from the television. 

I have a general problem with the deifying of Mildred. This woman is kind of a loser, she is a rude and generally unimpressive person who kind of just slobs around, getting gauded into random acts of violence... This is the woman Selman Hayek lauds as a paragon of female virtue. 

Even odder than all this is the handsome stranger who appears midway through the film. It seems like this guy who threatens McDormand in a mind bogglingly blatant way is crucial to the whole story! But why does this happen, why threaten her and make himself known? He must be very important right, and he is the same guy that Rockwell takes the DNA from AND he bragged about raping a woman... But according to the DNA it is not him who raped Angela... So sorry what was the point of him at all? To give something for McDormand and Rockwell to bond over? Why did he threaten her, why if he is from Idaho is he in Missouri?! Was he there to give McDormand a chance to enact some vigilante justice? Well we never get the chance to find out as the film just stops.  

While not a terrible film, it keeps a good pace largely, with some touching and emotional moments; there are just so many problems with the production that I for one cannot over look; even if the masses seem to have been seduced by the rampant white dude bashing. 

What has film come to?
The movie was well acted and very timely, but the language and violence bordered on being too much.

Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri ist ein Film der von Figurenkraft nur so strotzt. Alle Figuren werden sehr glaubhaft und vielschichtig gespielt. Man kann genau sehen, wie das Geschehene an den Menschen nagt und sie es teilweise versuchen zu verstecken. Vor allem Sam Rockwell spielt genial. Sein Charakter ist mein Favorit. Die Dialoge fühlen sich sehr real an, weil sie auch mal ausfällig werden. Die Geschichte wird in keiner Weise langweilig und auch nicht vorhersehbar. Dafür sorgt unter andrem auch sehr viel schwarzer Humor. Die Kamera ist während des Films meistens ruhig gehalten, was auch typisch für ein Drama ist. Dabei fängt sie aber auch Bilder ein die ich nicht so schnell vergessen werde. Die gemütliche Country Musik rundet das Seherlebnis perfekt passend ab. Meiner Meinung nach ist dieser Film ein Meisterwerk. Der Film erhält von mir definitiv die Höchstpunktzahl. 10/10

It just stops, there is no ending.

Martin McDonagh is back! After "In Bruges" and "Seven Psychopaths", he delivers yet another deliciously dark, engaging, funny movie that features sublime acting, excellent humour and multidimensional characters. It's an immersive film, McDonagh juggling the different moods more than adequately, although I have to say that he didn't seem to challenge himself much from a storyline perspective, avoiding to offer the subversiveness or climaxes that highlighted his previous work.
While a dark movie, the acting is as superb as its premise. Did not like the abrupt ending at all, however.

Life is a continuous struggle and nobody ever wins, until they stop fighting.  Those who keep struggling along end up turning against each other and become aggressors to both guilty and innocent. And this vicious circle never ends. This is the story of this film, one which seems at times to go out of its way in order to convinces the audience that it doesn't secretly root for any of its characters. But not to create a sort of balance beyond what life would have in store for these characters, or for this story, if they had been historical. It is not a film about crime and punishment. It is a film about failure, about powerlessness, about mortality, about the fact that at the end of great courage and great sacrifice there might not be any victory, or any justice, or even any truth.

Overall an excellent movie filled with a heavy a storyline peppered in with doses of well placed humor that packed an assisting punch to this movies tone. Loved Frances McDormand in this film; she was sensational. I think the powerful dialogue was delivered greatly by Frances. The movie flowed effortlessly and kept you on your toes. Even as I thought id could predict the storyline, I still enjoyed the ride and yet was still surprised by the screenplay. Was not completely fond of the ending, however, not everything ends how I think it should and it still is a decent ending. I might question that Margot Robbie (her "I, Tonya" performance) may have outperformed Frances, as Frances won the Oscar for Best Actress.

Character development and the sometimes raw interactions of them with each other is developed with the realism that few films ever are able to capture with feeling. There are two sides to every story and then there is the truth which may elude you forever.  The circumstances of the story in this movie are all real and show how tragic events are sometimes just that. Tragic. The effect these events have on the characters searching for the "who" and the "why me" ripples through the town and fabric of the people who live there leaving them all to deal with the fact that sometimes these complicated things never resolve themselves, and it falls to the characters to accept and deal with these realities because these realities are the only ones you are going to get.
Good, except I didn't like the ending at all, leaves too many questions.

This movie covers all the squares in indie bingo, including the unresolved ending, the alt rock soundtrack, Frances McDormand... But here's why the good reviews are puzzling -- it is so packed solid with stereotypes it can't breathe -- the racist, lazy, brutal Southern-ish cops, the bratty emo teenagers, the ex-husband with the young, cute and stupid girlfriend, the blue-collar small town, the noble black folks, and the beleaguered mom archetype.  As if to drive home the point that these cops are RACIST, they must use the n word, more than once.  Nice work by some of the minor characters though (the new police chief, Peter Dinklage, and disgraced cop Dixon's mom).  Essentially, this could have been a great movie with more script innovation.  I don't think this one will stick with me.

(4 out of 4) Three Billboards was one of 2017's most critically acclaimed films and I can agree with the praise it has received. The film centers around an angry mother dealing with the loss of her daughter who was murdered months ago. She is frustrated with the police's inadequacy with how they are handling the situation, so she decides to take matters in her own hands by renting out three billboards that send a message to the chief of police to do their job. It causes an uproar in the city. The billboards act is at the start of the film and movie focuses on a series of events that unfold that occur after the act. The first praise goes towards it having one of the finest casts of 2017. It stars Frances McDormand, Woody Harrelson, Sam Rockwell, as well as other recognizable faces. No characters feels out of place and they all act accordingly with the films tone. I will say that the character with the most moving performance is from Rockwell as a corrupt cop who undergoes a character arc that is at times devastating. It's always a challenge for a filmmaker to get you to feel for an unpleasant person, but the movie pulls it off by letting you spend extra time with the character and allowing you to witness his redemption. When it comes to what the movie is about (not the plot, but the themes), there has been debating about it. From my perspective, the movie seems to be about redemption, justice, and having the guts to take action. At the beginning, It seemed like it may go a police brutality route because of some things said by characters at the beginning, and adding on the fact that it is a topic discussed profusely in our culture. There may be something in there about the idea, but to be honest, I don't think it's about that. If there's anything else, I may have to look harder. Despite my confusion, I can say that the drama is always riveting and I was always curious to see how the movie unfolded. I love when a film transcends traditional narrative structure and avoiding falling under one genre. It's mostly dramatic, but offers dark comedy as well. It's among my Top 5 of the year.

'In Bruges' was a brilliant black comedy, 'Seven Psychopaths' was an up your arse abomination.  So what to expect from McDonagh's latest Oscar nominated effort.  Well it's very different from those previous films, but it's really quite brilliant.  Yes it is funny, but it's not a ha, ha comedy, it's normal back and forth banter.  It's funny in that effortless way that Tarantino used to be able to do and makes the characters all feel instantly more real and rounded as a result.  The central trio of  McDormand, Rockwell and in particular Harrelson are really brilliant and I was completely enthralled throughout.  There are one or two miss-steps (I really didn't like a glaring central CGI section) but other than that this is brilliant and I'll be intrigued to sit down and watch it again.

Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri has a heart. A big one. The film is rough and tough on the outside, but has a soft warm core. Just like its characters. They are all flawed. Some more than others. A lot more. They are all damaged. Some more than others. They all have something they feel guilty about. Some more than others. Some have more reason to than others. But they all care about one another, even if it seems early on that it couldn't be further from the truth. I could feel their hearts ache and it made mine ache too. A sprinkle of humor here and there acts like a good spice - bringing out the flavor of the whole thing. All that makes the movie immensely watchable. It's tragic. It's heartbreaking. Yet, I didn't want it to end.

I viewed this after the oscar awards as some actors/actresses won for their work.  the movie itself was simply good - not great - not bad.  the story itself is really flat for the most part and it's a movie that relies heavily on actors to develop real-life every day characters in a way that makes it a profound and telling experience for the viewer.  it is undeniable that frances mcdormand is a great actress as i have seen her in many other roles where she should have won an oscar for.  so, while she was very good in this role, i just don't think this role (not the actress) is oscar-worthy.  she is simply, due to her style, perfect for this particular film and particular role.  i think in that case the award should go to the casting director.  there are far more roles and characters out there that are much more challenging than this.  so that said, what was a stand-out character acted out in a stand-out way - was  sam rockwell. I can't recommend you waste your time with this movie. the entire plot is about a grieving redneck mother who recently experienced the unthinkable (her daughter was raped, tortured, and murdered and the killer is unknown and at large) and the controversy she causes when renting 3 town billboards to criticize local law enforcement. this is a nice plot, and had potential to create a powerful work of art, as it examined the feelings a grieving, frustrated mother would feel 7 months after this tragedy.

unfortunately frances mcdormand's character is a hollow shell of a grieving mother. i can't imagine any story, ever, where a grieving mother would have a clever toilet humor one liner about piss, shit, or cunts, every 2 minutes... but that's what we get here.

the director has juvenile story pushing sensibilities in a lot of ways. constantly destroys the momentum of his real, personal moments with inappropriate gags and jokes. constantly recreates his characters on the spot when convenient for the story (really? a racist, uneducated, woman hating cop who has a history of violently torturing multiple innocent people, by the grace of god, gets sent to travel a redemption arc?) it's so laughably messy and manipulative.

the worst part of all though, the director decides that he wants you to invest 2 hours of your life into a movie that has a vague, unsatisfactory ending with no closure or no real answers. there are no rules to creativity, but there are rules to storytelling... and to tell a great story, you need to deliver a conclusion. leaving your viewers uncertain isn't a strength... it's a weakness.... and it means you were too much of a pussy to commit to an ending.

This film is one of the best films of the year. The acting was legendary. I liked that someone who is so rough around the edges like Mildred Hayes has such a kind heart and soul. Clearly, she was tortured inside by her daughter's demise however, she carried on the best that she could while fighting her battle and staying true to her vision. she didn't have any prejudice against minorities and stood up for the african american plight of police abuse, she cared beautifully for the flowers that decorated the ground of the billboards and was very gentle with the visiting deer. She came across as so brusque but inside there was extreme goodness. Mildred will use that beauty inside to make the world a better place even if it doesn't help her directly. I loved how officer Dixon changed because Officer Willoughby believed in him. It was a great example of the deep power of kindness. This movie was definitely a stretch for me because of the violence and the disturbing theme. But, I made is through and I am glad that I did. It left an impression. Highly recommend

"Three Adverts for a Crime," a visceral film that tinkers with the viewer's entrails, blending comedy, drama, and suspense, the film is both ponderous and intriguing, full of social criticism and great acting and directing. best film among the nominees of ocar the category of "best film". When we talk about the script, something that awakens our attention, we expect the script to be adapted, but we are surprised to know that it is an original script, which makes the film even more interesting, since it opens many margins for the good director and screenwriter Martin McDonagh, telling the story of a mother indignant at the death of her daughter unresolved by the police, the film creates a context, and within it inserts its characters, some very caricature, but all very deep, or at least with some development, in addition, the long builds characters to then break, weaken and raise them again. The film talks about racism, violence, abuse of authority, homicide and domestic violence, of course, a pure feeling of impotence to be fought, the film is a machine gun for criticism, even though they are all exaggerated in absurd contexts. it is no longer a critical movie. Technically, the film is very good, with a greater emphasis on its great editing, composition of scenes, and great angles, open, with planes sequences, traveling, the camera of the film behaves perfectly, in addition to a photograph that warm, remembering a good old western. Frances McDormand is completely amazing, frightening and crazy, the character scares, and makes the viewer buy his idea, besides showing his sweet and ferocious moments, the other highlight goes to Sam Rockwell, who for me is the best character of the film, a character broken by nature, a class on how to build an antagonist, without vanity or modesty, Woody Harrelson too, is charming and captivating, even having little screen time. Finally, "Three ads for a crime" is not perfect, far from it, has problems, has scenes explained that do not need to be explained, has moments that is disconnected with the context that created, but still, it is a very good movie .

One thing is for sure. If you ever decide to go into the advertising billboard business don't plan on using  Ebbing, Missouri as your launch pad. They make would-be advertisers use giant sized billboards on a back road where no one will see them and where eventually they will obviously fall into disrepair. This is where Mildred, (Frances McDormand) comes in. A curmudgeonly and waspish woman, who is seeking action from the local police in finding her missing daughter's abductor and, we must assume, her eventual killer. Mildred decides to rent the billboards to grab police attention and advertise in oversized black text the lack of police commitment.

The numerous preposterous situations in this film can be attributed to a lethal combination of a writer who feels ill at ease with story telling and fatally treats his words as holy writ. He should have had a strong director with him to flag up the flimsy logic and horrid clichés. A director who wouldn't let him get away with it.  Unfortunately, when the two of them got together, their admiration for each other's work was so intense and resilient,  they just couldn't bring themselves to openly question the other's thought process. But they must have both had their suspicions about each other because the flaws want to sort themselves out as the film goes along. Tanker loads of midnight oil must have been burnt beavering away on adding bits to get the plot to catch up and explain itself.
Sadly, this film lacks that thread of logic that must exist for an audience to truly believe in the plot. Logic should be the cornerstone. Give an audience a logical story and they will follow. Toy Story, Superman, etc. all fantasy, but all fiercely logical.
In any event, both the writer and the director finally gave up on logic and relied instead on three huge, sleight of hand performances to cover any inconvenient truths.

This film is a mass of contradictions. It has no sense of location. For a start there are few stores in this town.  There are no grocery stores or McDonalds or anything - or if there are we don't get to see them. We just don't know where we are - or even in what time zone.  But hang on, I'm forgetting that's not necessary because it's in the title. It's Ebbing, Missouri. And it's about Three Billboards. And they're outside town. 

Now, just like the lack of stores in Ebbing, the townsfolk are sparse and a weird bunch too. There aren't that many of them but all have presumably been extras in Westerns for most of their lives and as a result stand around on Main Street watching meekly as one of Ebbing's finest, a twerpy, semi-literate cop (Sam Rockwell) inflicts violence on the aforementioned, mild mannered citizens. 
But no one notices. No one complains. It's as though a part of this town has been set aside to allow a manic theatre troupe to indulge in a sub-culture of idiocy of truly Truman Show proportions.
There's the obligatory drunk police chief - no wait a minute, that's Sam Rockwell, he's the drunk but he's not the chief. The police chief is Woody Harrelson and he has a terminal illness but other than that, only the scantest of other clues to his character.
We know he is married to a young Australian girl (Abbie Cornish). Who says Hollywood can no longer contemplate a ludicrous age gap? But the Cornish character was presumably on a doomed domestic flight from Sydney to somewhere when she found herself stranded in the twilight zone that is Ebbing.  

Harrelson and Cornish have two children who are cute and play a curious fishing game by themselves on the edge of a lake. This allows their parents  to treat themselves to some off screen hanky-panky and because of this their childrens' safety is rather secondary.  Harrelson's quiet performance, in a wonderful white shirt, has echoes of Jeff Bridges in 'Hell or High Water'. Although that's where the comparison ends. He really exists only in the mind of the director or writer,  or both of them, to compose three hand written letters that will get our director or the writer off a troublesome hook and make everything right for everybody. 
Then, finally there's Frances McDormand as Mildred , our Three Bill Boards girl. Now, anyone who has seen Ms. McDormand in previous productions will have fond memories of Fargo and Blood Simple and Olive Kitteredge and so on. But, and let's be clear about this,  Frances McDormand could waltz through this sort of script while asleep. On a stretcher. In the dark.  A ground breaking performance it is not.  It's as though she planned to try something else but, and Pavlov was right on this, as soon as an actor sees a red light and hears a bell many of them just can't help but deliver their stock performance. 
In McDormand's case it's from her Sour and Harsh canon and regrettably she will not develop beyond this now as an actress.  

So what does all this strange little film add up to? Probably, just like La La Land, it proves you can fool all of the people some of the time - even an Oscar jury.
My memory of Three Billboards will be the indulgent script and lack of editing and Sam Rockwell's strange haircut and Frances McDormand's relentless bandana and strange haircut and Clarke Peters flashing his cop's badge a little too early -  so when an elderly 'Sidney Poitier' shows up in town our surprise 
is muted. 
Oddly, and this is a clue to how a film can mask the insubstantial talent of the writer and director, the minor roles here only serve to amplify the massive theatricality of the principal performances and the production as a whole. 

And so it will fade away and get an Oscar for something, the fraud is complete and the game can go on.
SO GOOD! Deserved every nomination and win it got. Amazingly melancholic and a scarily true ending.

Three Billboards has quickly become the most overrated movie of the year. This is not to say the movie is bad or even ok, it is a very good movie; but there are major problems and I personally don’t think it’s close to being the best picture of the year. First let’s talk about the good. Pretty much all of the acting is top notch. Frances McDormand, Woody Harrelson, and Sam Rockwell are all fantastic and deserving of whatever awards they win. Martin McDonagh did a great job of getting the very best performances out of his guys. The plot is also very interesting and allows the film to explore some very complicated themes. Now for the bad. The film covers some very heavy topics and when any film does this, it is important for the audience to believe the world so that these topics are taken seriously. I felt that Sam Rockwell’s character was so over the top that is was unbelievable. This subsequently makes his transformation unbelievable and his transformation is a crucial part of the movie. I feel that most of the characters are a bit over the top is this made some of the scenes and character arcs less believable for me. In the end, the acting and plot are good enough for me to see past the over the top characters, but those problems do keep the film from being something truly special.

Was this written by a teenager? Literally everything that happens is so absurd and inconsequential. The cheesy monologues on morbidity sound so naive and void of any real life experience, it's hard to believe this filmmaker has ever had anything actually bad ever happen to him. It's frankly the wet dream of some Hollywood screenwriter's ideal feminist hillbilly woman who don't give no darn-tootins.

So why is this movie so highly regarded on critic sites? Because 1. the acting is great and 2. critics are so blinded by their politics in 2018 the actual quality of a film doesn't matter. It delivers the message they want to hear, so it's the greatest movie ever made. Rinse and repeat.

Bordering somewhere between a dark comedy and being overly dramatic, "Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri" is a not-so-feel-good film that takes viewers down unexpected lesser explored roads in our modern film-making era.  The main plot: bereaved mother Mildred Hayes pays for three billboards that blatantly call out the town's police chief as she desperately wants to know why they're not doing more to find her daughter's killer. And from there, a spawn of ideas and emotions get strung out for the viewer to follow along with.  

What I mostly loved about this film was 1) that it paints small-town life in the middle of our country in a realistic and beautiful fashion; 2) that Frances McDormand's performance is solid; and 3) that it's presenting a story about reconciliation that I didn't see coming.  But most importantly, 4) the story has multiple layers to its narrative that enrich it more than I'd expected.  For example, at one point a character has ear-buds in and is listening to the song "Chiquitita" by ABBA.  When it started, the audience giggled because it seems humorous.  But a few hours  after I saw the film, I looked up the lyrics to "Chiquitita" and saw that they fit the story-line at that point in the film so well that I was almost mad at myself for not catching the connection while I was watching it.  Another example: at the beginning of the film, a character is reading the short story collection "A Good Man is Hard to Find" by Flannery O'Connor, and that book's title becomes a supporting theme throughout the entire movie. 

The only things that didn't work so well with me were 1) the pervasive language -- after hearing the characters use the F word about 500 times, I was beginning to wonder if we'd run out of words in the English language; and 2) the politics of our current era were a bit more present than I'd have cared for -- Really? The seemingly bad guys are both a racist policeman and a war veteran?  Really?! -- Folks, I go to the movies to escape the pain of our nowadays, not to be reminded of it.  HOWEVER, one thing this movie does that few films pull off is this: you think you're rooting for one or two characters at the beginning of the film, but by the end you might find yourself rooting for the opposite characters.  And this ability to consider all sides of a story, argument, or discussion is something that America desperately needs to re-learn. (On a side-note: the film's writer/director is British.  Just sayin'...)

All in all: it's an extremely well-made movie, but it was a bit too dark for me to want to watch it again anytime soon.  [3/5 stars]

"Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri" is not as much about what its premise suggests at first glance, as is about the vanity & pointlessness of certain actions.

McDormand, Harrelson & Rockwell deliver some powerful, brilliant performances in this unconventional drama written & directed by Martin McDonagh.

The film revolves around two opposing driving forces that pit characters against each other. Chief Willoughby & his illness act like teachers preaching to people how they should behave & what to change in order to transform into the best version of themselves they can be. An idealistic, uphill battle against the other driving force, the phrase "Anger begets greater anger" which seems to win over its opponent for the majority of the film. 

Every action in "Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri" has a reaction from another character & almost all reactions are of the negative side. The message of the film is clear. Only when we abolish our anger & replace it with love, we can start our healing process.
Somehow it was super sad yet light hearted and really funny. Also had 2 or 3 painful to watch moments. Great movie.

Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri is one of the greatest films of 2017 and an eye-opening account of a woman trying to seek justice for her daughters death. Set in the small town of Ebbing, Missouri, a woman, Mildred Hayes (Frances McDermond) decides to rent three billboards to bring attention to her daughters rape and murder after no convict was brought forward. She receives a great deal of backlash from the community and the police force which features Sheriff Bill Willoughby (Woody Harrelson) and Officer Jason Dixon (Sam Rockwell). All of the performances by these three leads are outstanding, and it is no surprise that they have all been nominated for numerous awards for their roles. Harrelson's character has many other tragedies to deal with in his life besides the case, and is easy to forgive and be sympathetic towards once we find out his entire story. Rockwell's Dixon, is a very racist and ignorant officer, but his story grows dramatically over the entire film. McDermond's Mildred is a very strong woman, but the film does a great job showing her resilience and determination in seeking justice for her daughter. The film is very much a dark drama and gives great insight into what life is like in the small towns of the American south. There is a lot of foul language and unpunished crime, but this is just what life is like in the Deep South. The story is very interesting and sympathetic, and deals with real life issues and tragedies. The pacing is good as events build off one another and storylines connect. The dialogue is also top notch, which the writers and director should be given credited for. The ending leaves many question unanswered but seems a fitting way to wrap up this dark and sympathetic tragedy. Overall, Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri is a masterpiece. The performances are top notch, the writing is excellent, and the film does a great job of shining light on tragedy and small town life in the Deep South from multiple perspectives.

A film for a mature audience. The characters are complex and their relationships are real life. There is good and evil, but nobody has an monopoly on either. The film shifts gear around the pivotal event, but both halves deliver a desolate beauty. This is not a film for you if you want resolution, but if you can accept the realities of life, go see it.
Not bad. The main message isn't well thought out, but the whole thing is entertaining. Kind of an unserious film disguised as a serious one though.

It was *mostly* interesting with sharp dialogue and scenes, but ultimately this film falls victim to its own clever premise - when you start a film with a question writ large "who killed this girl?" you can only spend so long not figuring that out. A lot of hype around "performances", but it will be forgotten in a few years, even if it wins best picture.

Strengths: There is no better written movie from 2017 and that's high praise considering how great this year was for film. The dialogue is sharp and the characters are incredibly fleshed out. All three main characters have clear flaws and it makes them such a treat to watch. it helps that the performances are incredible. Frances McDormand (Mildred Hayes) is unbelievable. She's winning all the awards and I get it. It's not just the single best performance of the year, it's one the greatest I've ever seen. Woody Harrelson (Bill) brings a sympathy to his character. He's a cop, who are the group that Mildred is at odds with, but you feel for him and his condition. It's not a major scene, but the one of him and Mildred in the interrogation room is very moving. Sam Rockwell (Jason) does fantastic as the racist, alcoholic officer who seems irredeemable, but turns things around quite nicely, giving him a fully developed arc. The script does a masterful job of balancing the dark, heartbreaking stuff, with just enough comedy. There's a realness to everything that happens that adds so much to it all. Also, I want to commend the people with the smaller roles. Samara Weaving (Penelope) was hilarious, Peter Dinkalge (James) was his great self, and Abbie Cornish (Anne) showed a lot of emotion in her short screen time.

Weaknesses: If I had to pick an issue, it would be the ending. It's not a bad one, but it just kind of feels like it falls a bit flat. As you watch the movie, you're expecting it to lead to something big and instead, it kind of just ends.

Overall: Even with an ending that I wouldn't exactly consider perfect, it doesn't do enough harm to take away from just how incredible this movie is. It's gripping, emotional, and real. It's packed with so many stellar performances and you can't peel your eyes away from it all.

This movie confused me. I wasn't quite sure if this movie was a mediocre drama with some failed attempts at humor or a mediocre comedy with some failed attempts at drama. 
The premise is interesting, a mother trying to provoke the local police into solving the murder of her daughter. The local police are portrayed at once as intimidating (they seem to fill the streets with cop cars and marauding cops on the high street terrifying passers-by) and as racist and violent incompetents who have to hunt through dozens of pockets in order to find their badges. The story seemed to meander through various stereotypes until it turns out we were supposed to sympathize with the racist cop and his bullying chief after all. 
I can't believe this was nominated for best picture.

Dark and violent yet also heartbreaking and sweet, dramatic and serious yet also very funny at times, Three Billboards is such a tonally diverse film which fires on all cylinders and succeeds both as a terrific crime drama as well as an effective black comedy. It is undoubtedly the best acted film of the year with the performances from Frances McDormand and Sam Rockwell being the powerhouse standouts. It has a number of memorable scenes, it deals with complicated issues in a sophisticated manner and it's superbly directed by Martin McDonagh while also being very well scored and brilliantly paced. Consequently, Three Billboards is the very best film of 2017.

Was Three Billboards a great Film? You Betcha...... I'm sorry. Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri is the new film from Martin McDonagh, the excellent director of In Bruges. This is a Fargo-esq black comedy about a woman who takes on her local town over the death of her daughter. Francis McDormand gives possibly her best performance as the single mother of the murdered girl. Sam Rockwell is excellent, and gives maybe my favorite supporting performance of the year. Actually, most of the performances are excellent. Also, the movie goes in a lot of unexpected and fantastic ways that I didn't expect. Definitely a highlight of 2017.

A great film with heart and staying power. Watching a mother, Frances McDormand, at the end of her rope come up with the idea to push the police into action captures the heart. McDormand pulls out the performance of a lifetime, which is saying something when compared to Fargo, and captures the audience's attention from the first scene. Director/Writer Martin McDonagh really gets the best out of all his cast in this film. Sam Rockwell, who is always great, was better than his normal brilliance, and a shoe in for best supporting actor. The story is small but shows what a parent who has lost a child is willing to do to capture the perpetrator. I love the mood and fine throughout this picture and can't wait for the next film from McDonagh. The bug negative I had was with the casting of Woody Harleson's wife. She is obviously young enough to be his daughter and had an Australian accent that had no business in the movie. Other than that the film is a triumph and will find plenty of love come award season.

Martin McDonagh's (In Bruges, 7 Psychopaths) "Three Billboards Outside, Ebbing Missouri", takes a sharp script and fantastic performances only to then have the film fizzle out by the end. Everyone in the movie is great but Sam Rockwell and Frances McDormand carry the movie. While I do have a problem with how McDormand's character was written, she still gives a fantastic showy performance and Sam Rockwell's character is the only character in the film who 
has any sort of arc. 

McDonagh's script does a mostly great job at balancing between being very Dark/dramatic and comedic. I do think that there are moments in the movie where dramatic tension was undercut with jokes, at times it felt like he was trying to mimic the Coen Brothers. I also found the some of the writing to be ham fisted at times. 

My biggest problem with this movie though is its ending. After the movie ends I felt that the movie was lacking something. Throughout the film we are building up to something only for the movie come to an abrupt ending. It felt like he was trying to go for a sort "No Country for Old Men" ending. 

I also had problems with "No Country for Old Men" ending but the more I watched it the more I liked it. Maybe the same thing could be said for "Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri". 

Final Score: 4/5 or 8 out of 10

My pic for best actress is Frances McDormand for her wonderfully heart wrenching yet funny performance in Three Billboards. Three Billboards Outside of Ebbing Missouri had it all.  It was funny, dramatic, scary, and heartwarming all throughout the film.  This movie is about a mother whose daughter was murdered 7 months ago and no police advancements had been made.  In anger she rents out three billboards calling out the police.  The rest of the movie is everyones reactions to these billboards.  It is hard to say what happens without spoiling the movie but I'll try.  There was three different explosions, one suicide, five different beatings, someone getting thrown out of a window and a whole lot of swearing.  Frances McDormand (Best Actress) gives a wonderful performance, but there is one main problem.  There is no character development, she stays in the same spot at the end of the movie that she was in at the beginning.  On the contrary, Sam Rockwell (Best Supporting Actor) gives one of the best performances of the year with his racist attitude that changes throughout the movie. The real shining star of the movie is definitely Woody Harrelson(Best Supporting Actor).  He gives the best performance of his career by far.  He is funny and heartbreaking at the same time.
Frances McDormand is so into her role in this film.  Worth seeing just for her performance.

Nú þegar Óskarinn fer að nálgast eru bíósalir landsins að springa undan glænýjum, stundum skrítnum en oftast áhugaverðum myndum. Ein sú mest áberandi í þessu kapphlaupi er Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri. Að mínu mati hefur Three Billboards líklegast aðeins einn áberandi galla: frekar langt, óþjált nafn.

Þetta er þriðja kvikmyndin í fullri lengd sem er leikstýrð af Martin McDonagh, sem gerði þar á undan In Bruges og Seven Psychopaths (báðar frábærar á sinn hátt. Má með sanni segja að hér hefur Martin náð sínum toppi (vonandi hingað til) en hér sameinast frábær leikstjórn, ótrúlegur leikarahópur, átakanleg saga og tilfinningaþrungið andrúmsloft. Grunnur sögunnar er barátta einnar konu við lögregluna í Ebbing, Missouri. Hins vegar fléttast inn í þetta barátta við kerfið í heild sinni, bæinn sjálfan, sorg, söknuð og mismunun. Það besta við söguna er hversu mikil persónusköpun á sér stað þrátt fyrir mergðina af flóknum, áhugaverðum persónum.

Úr leikarahópnum eru að mínu mati hápunktarnir tveir: Frances McDormand og Sam Rockwell. McDormand leikur eina hörðustu, flottustu persónu sem ég hef séð lengi, og er ógleymanleg í sínu hlutverki. M.v. þær myndir sem ég hef hingað til séð (margar eftir, hins vegar) er engin leikkona sem á meira skilið Óskarinn fyrir sitt hlutverk. Rockwell leikur hins vegar hlutverk sem ég hef sjaldan séð en vil ég ekki fara nánar út í hans persónuleika svo það komi sem mest á óvart. Þetta eru einungis hápunktarnir en allt leikaraliðið stendur sig prýðilega.

Three Billboards er ein allrabesta mynd ársins 2017, sem var almennt séð mjög sterkt kvikmyndaár. Endilega kíkið á hana meðan að sýningar eru í gangi, ekta mynd til að skella sér á í bíó ;)

A black comedy traversing through a searing drama where a mother of a raped daughter rents out 3 billboards near her home, which read, in sequence, "Raped While Dying", "And Still No Arrests?", and "How Come, Chief Willoughby?" as the perpetrator is not nabbed. How the quiet serene hamlet townbags of the fictional Missouri town react and turn into a new leaf is what forms the rest of the story.

McDonaugh has asserted that he got the idea from a real life billboard (which I remember seeing on Facebook some years ago)  makes sure he has a pumped screenplay with some suitable score, topped by his veteran actors neat performances by Frances McDormand, Sam Rockwell,  Woody Harrelson; which ended up in all 3 being nominated. 

McDormand was in the limelight on telly for OliveKittiridge and now she catapulted back to her Fargo days on cinema with a finely nuanced display of emotions with a slight shifts in expressions,  slapped on your faces with some scandalising slurs! Rockwell as the racist police officer ably supports her with an equally organic performance which bowls you over. Harrelson IMO wasn't that great! 

What's more interesting is that with the recent series of school shootings,  atleast 4 towns in USA have used this strategy to throw light on the ghastly incidents.

A rollercoaster of relentless bleakness mixed with dark humour serving to deepen both. Frances McDormand is great as Mildred, a role written by Martin McDonagh with her in mind. We follow Mildred as she confronts the police with their failure to find her daughter's murderer and as the extent of the pain of the memories she is dealing with is revealed. Sam Rockwell is, as always, consumed in his character as Officer Dixon; a contemptible, ignorant and racist thug. Although the evolution of the character of Dixon in the film has been criticised, this does not diminish Rockwell's ability as we come to question whether Dixon would be a different man under influences other than his own ignorant and poisonous mother..The emotional ping pong of the script and the beautifully constructed visual images and sequences produce an atmosphere that gets inside your head.

How this movie was nominated for Best Picture is beyond me. It has a 'trying too hard' feeling. Although rooted in a plausible central dilemma, the story has too many absurd plot twists, unrealistic outcomes, and dialogue better suited to LA than Missouri. Speaking as a Democrat living in California, the not-so-subtle progressivism projected into some of the characters came across as forced, not necessary to the story and not believable. The setting, editing and cinematography are the only noteworthy parts of the film but one last gripe - if Ebbing is not a real town and the film was shot in North Carolina, why not just use the real thing?

I was not overly taken in initially with the hype this film seems to have gathered. I mean, the premise, title and trailer all failed to provide much anticipation. However I do recommend this film is seen.
The performances from the cast are the highlight.
The basic plot outline is the grieving mother Mildred (Frances McDormand) whose daughter was murdered quite violently some months before.
She seems to think the police investigation has gone a bit dormant. So in order to focus the mind of locally respected police chief Willoughby (Woody Harrelson) she hires some dilapidated old billboards on a little used road outside the local town of Ebbing, Missouri, USA.
McFarland delivers a fantastic performance not only in grief and revenge but a black humour.
Harrelson starts the film looking as if he will be an unpopular character but when it is revealed he is dying from cancer he displays a more sympathetic and at times humorous performance.
Willoughby is aided by apparently racist cop, Dixon (Sam Rockwell). Rockwell to delivers a great performance as his character turns from low IQ/racist cop to concerned investigator after his sacking and death of Willoughby.
I had one major gripe with this film. The debatable ending.
Now I prefer more black and white endings.
The simplistic film title has now caused mass attention and debate after viewing and for this I commend the film.
if I were to make a list for 2017s best films, this film would easily be in the top 3.

I have to admit that for the 1st time in about 25 years I am well behind the 8 ball when it comes to this years Academy Award nominees. Right now the frotn runners appear to be The Shape of Water, a movie where a deaf woman has sex with a fish, and Dunkirk which has about 10 lines of dialogue in the entire film. But I was lucky enough to go and see Three Billboards tonight and I have to admit this was one of the best screenplays I have ever seen on the big screen. This movie has so many unforeseen twists and turns that it takes you on a roller coaster ride unlike anything Disney World has to offer. Frances McDormand and Sam Rockwell should be shoe ins for their respective categories of Best Actress and Supporting Actor and I have not doubt that Director/Writer Martin McDonagh should be taking home the little gold man for his story. A highly recommended 2 hours

'THREE BILLBOARDS' embarks on its tour of darkness with a simple, surgically-refined story and a host of incredible performances. Martin McDonagh expertly adapts his own script into a thoroughly compelling cinematic experience with some of the sharpest dialogue of the year, enacted with perfection by the amazing Frances McDormand, Woody Harrelson, Peter Dinklage, and Sam Rockwell (who delivers one of the best performances of his already excellent career). McDonagh clearly knows his cast perfectly, unleashing their greatest individual and collective strengths to drive forward his dark tale of crime in small town America. The comedy is here as well, and delivered flawlessly, and never does a second feel wasted.

Promising start - could have been much stronger if it had kept closer to realism.  It became more about acting and less about character exploration.  Views of the small town society are Hollywood fantasy that the center of our country has pretty countryside and dreadful people.  Some of the acting is really good, but it is a mixed bag overall, and not award worthy.  They blew this one.

I went into this film knowing nothing about it other than the fact that Frances McDormand was in it, which is enough for me to want to see any movie. I left it and had all kinds of emotions. And I'm wondering if maybe that's the point of the whole thing. I was shocked (by the violence and subject matter), depressed (for almost every character in the movie), and confused (by Peter Dinklage's purpose and by a scene that felt like it was key to the plot, but turned out to be seemingly extraneous). But I also felt satisfied and as always, I was impressed by Frances McDormand and frankly, the rest of the cast. To echo many critics, the movie is beautifully acted all-around and that's its driving force. The writing is a bit too on-the-nose for my tastes and it's fence-hopping between being a dark comedy and a darker drama leaves your vision blurry at times. And the more I look at it, the more I feel like Three Billboards is Martin McDonagh's attempt at a Coen Brothers' movie. But it had solid pacing, subtle use of music, tons of charm, and....Frances McDormand. Would this one stand the test of time? Absolutely not (it'll be a hard-to-remember trivia answer in five years), but it's still worthy of its multiple nominations.

And who are those two to decide to go kill someone for an alleged rape of a different girl he may or may not have committed?!? She's an irredeemably poor excuse for a mother and an arsonist to boot who almost murdered Sam Rockwell and he is a racist, sexist, violent attempted murderer already...if they are looking for justice they should start with themselves. And what kind of hillbilly version of Keystone cops do they have in that town (can't solve a rape case, can't charge a deputy for attempted murder committed in broad daylight on Main Street in front of scores of witnesses, beat up innocent citizens for sport, racist as hell and can't solve an incredibly simple arson case)....hell I'm going to get rich by robbing banks in MO because, according to this film, they are all a bunch of idiots! Also, who drives around with a giant fire extinguisher in their car...I mean that thing is huge? And speaking of huge, she owns a big beautiful house (look at the exterior shots) yet its kind of a shithole on the inside and she watches the local newscast on a tiny tv from the 80's (complete with dials to change the channel)...I mean, a small flat screen is  cheap as chips at Walmart....are you telling me those shit kickers don't have a goddamn Walmart in that town? And speaking of money (Wendy pointed this out) considering that the Sheriff planed to kill himself and leave the family with no breadwinner, was that really the time to waste $5,000 on a freakin billboard? Lash out.  So this is the story about a mother (Frances McDormand) who lost her daughter in a horrific crime.  Months have passed, and the local law enforcement is ready to write the case off as being unsolvable because they have no leads.  She decides to push the issue and rent three billboards so as to remind the police that this isn't just going away.  Now this was one of the movies that I was most looking forward to all year.  It's from Martin McDonagh who has written some of my favorite dark stories not only for the screen, but for the stage as well.  He clearly has some personal demons that he exorcises through his writing, and I highly recommend you take time with both In Bruges and The Pillowman.  This is his new original work, and it did not disappoint.  I know I must sound like a broken record at this point, but I have to say it again: this is yet another movie that was pitched to me as a dark comedy, but it features a subject matter that really didn't allow me to laugh all that much.  That said, I could tell what this movie really was about pretty early on, so I was able to adjust fairly quickly.  This is a pitch black heavy story that is not afraid to get in your face.  It is all brought to life with some knockout performances, especially from Frances McDormand.  This is the best she has been since Fargo (which is saying something), and she is excellent as this tough-as-nails woman with a vendetta.  I don't think there is going to be a whole lot of surprises this Oscar ceremony, because I think that she is a lock to win for Best Actress, and she really does deliver that flooring of a performance.  Also worth mentioning is the performances of the local police force in Woody Harrelson and Sam Rockwell.  They are effectively playing country folk to the point of being natural, and that makes it all the easier to get into the story.  I do really like how you can see multiple points of view in this and understand where everybody is coming from.  I know this has faced a bit of backlash due to one of the characters having a racist history, and to be fair, there is plenty about this that will make you cringe, but it does make it feel authentic.  Realistically, if you are dealing with people that are this backwater, you're going to see deep seeded racism that has been passed down for generations, and that just is something that you can't tiptoe around.  There is a lot of emotional weight to this, and I could easily see this being translated for a stage production, it is just how Martin McDonagh writes.  This is an uncomfortable drama that has a number of great scenes to it, and I recommend it.

Great acting in this film about the mother of a murdered teen who tries to disgrace the local law into action by posting 3 large billboards calling them out about not taking action against her daughter's rape and murder. This act of rage, guilt, and desperation incites a domino effect in the people of the town, with innocent people caught up in the crossfire both physically and emotionally. This movie is dark, sad, and violent. Lots of profanity and prejudice in this hick town suffering from the unsolved, violent murder of the local teen. The people of this town have a love-hate relationship with each other and they act out everything they feel. It makes you think about emotions, and reactions to emotions, and consequences for reactions to emotions. Three wrongs definitely don't make a right!

Many people have labelled Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri as one of the best films of the year. Upon seeing it, I can certainly verify that this is a very good film. Academy Award winner Martin McDonagh directs this ambitious flick, which succeeds as a balance of black comedy and harshly realistic drama. The story tells of divorced mother Mildred Hayes (Frances McDormand) who wages war with the police department with her town, instigated by three, inflammatory billboards questioning a lack of clarity in her daughter's murder case. The film does not sound fun and in many ways it isn't; at points, the film showcases scenes of raw emotion, interspersed with often surprisingly brutal violence. At other times, the film is a deliciously black comedy; the two tones successfully work together, not combating but complimenting eachother. The real achievement of this film is the performances by its veteran cast, led by Frances McDormand whose performance as tragic Mildred Hayes ranges from blunt hilarity to sheer passion and emotion. McDormand is simply fantastic, both determined and defeated; what this actress can convey only in a stare is astounding. Sam Rockwell, an Oscar favourite for his role, is very believable as thuggish cop, Dixon, despite a slightly unbelievable redemption that does come too easy. Woody Harrelson is also great, as are the rest of the cast, despite some, such as Lucas Hedges playing Mildred's bullied son, feeling underused. Three Billboards, though providing us with some incredible scenes and expert cinematography and design, is prone to subplots and tangents, such as Mildred's relationship with her ex-husband, which, while sometimes benefiting the main narrative, sometimes crowd the screen and hinder the film. Halfway through, the film enters a rather chaotic sequence which gives the film a disjointed feel that it fights hard to redeem. 
Despite its mistakes, I find it impossible not to respect this film in its ambition, honesty and deft execution. This film is very funny, but its also very heart-breaking and real. The film is successful in its ambiguity of its characters; characters like Mildred and Dixon are pretty horrible in many things they do, but beneath their acts you can clearly see their motivations and how it is not out of malice that they do what they do, but out of the toxicity of rage and hurt, which McDonagh presents so thoughtfully.
Overall, Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri may not be the best film of this year, but it remains a film that is humorous, delightfully brutal but also very beautiful in its own way, striking and remarkably thoughtful.
