El film, siendo promocionado como una obra de "drama y comedia negra", acierta en estos dos puntos con creces, sin disminuir el ritmo en ninguna secuencia. Por momentos, impredecible y cruelmente sorprendente, la historia de una mujer dolida que lucha por abrir nuevamente la investigación inconclusa sobre el asesinato de su hija, es uno de los puntos fuertes por el cual la película gana peso argumental. Sin embargo, no es lo único. Ciertamente el film está conformado por personajes entrañables, identificables a primera vista, con los que uno podría equivocarse si los llega a considerar unidimesionales. La riqueza de lo impredecible, junto con altas dosis de critica social, y el acertado abordaje de temas vigentes sobre discriminación y abuso de autoridad, ponen en alto a esta propuesta contemporánea del cine crudo, realista, pero con mucho corazón...quizá, demasiado para un cliffhanger que podría convencer o no a la audiencia. Pero esto último dependerá del gusto particular de cada uno.
Como describir esta pelicula, es una tragicomedia. Sin duda Francis se merece el Oscar, pero esta no es la mejor pelicula del año. Pero estamos en tiempos en que ya no sabe lo que hacen.

Not for the faint of heart or those who want their violence and anger served up as Marvel or D.C. revenge and explosions, war or in a horror movie.  NO, the violence in "Three Billboards" clearly reflects seething anger and rage.  As the movie unfolds it opens up in to the pain, the all consuming pain seemingly that pervades this fictional southern town.  Ebbing is a setting, a myth or archetype of a place where decent people fade in to the background, barely noticed by the bitter denizens of this mythical location.  The angry dominate the foreground, while intriguing multi-dimensional characters, get ignored, beaten or harm themselves.  The movie is engrossing.  The dialogue is taut and the acting is superb throughout.  If you want to bask in existential sorrow with humans desperate for connection but unable to find it, those tossed to the purgatory of regret, of opportunity missed in relationship and profound, unbearable regret, this is your film.  It is powerful, poignant and you will leave with a distinct experience, a take on the film, stirred up and even a bit befuddled.  No clean endings, no clear hero or villain except the unknown assailant who committed the atrocity proclaimed on those 3 billboards. The billboards, they stand like the trinity crying out for something holy, and like a Springsteen song announcing that this is a town for losers, and as a last ditch effort for a mother to find salvation from her own family failings.I recommend the film without hesitation.
There is nothing wrong with this Film in all aspects of film making and is a perfect example of what films can be and the stories that can be told.

Unpleasant and pointless, despite terrific performances.  It's misleading to call this a dark comedy.  That would imply an intelligent use of humor, and some point of view. I watched through a series of relentless sadness, unpleasant characters and indefensible actions on all (well, most all) ends, waiting for something to take away from the film, something besides all the misery.   But plot points came and went  without ramification or meaning (e.g., someone starts a serious fire late in the film, everyone knows who did it, but even the culprit's enemies don't press an investigation - why is that?).   And the dialogue is frequently embarrassing, depending on a slew of expletives to show down-to-earthness and anger and ignorance and love.  I'm not kidding, be prepared for a parent to cuss at his little children to show affection.  There are great performances here, but  Ms.McDormand can't compensate for the fact that she plays a relentlessly unpleasant character that stubbornly refuses to develop.

Dexterous writer-director Martin McDonagh never fails to find pitch-black comedy in the bleakest of premises, and Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri, is no exception.

This peculiar picture charts the strategic exploits of a cranky single mother (Frances McDormand) as she tries to draw 14ft-high, 48ft-wide attention to the unsolved murder of her teenage daughter, x3.

The film takes place in a fictitious deadbeat town that's so deadbeat, it's presumably where echoes of unwanted beats come to die. This is a place populated by small men of dubious morals and intelligence, which include an amusing, bumbling Sam Rockwell and a sanctimonious Woody Harrelson in outlandish dumb cop, twat cop roles.

McDonagh has a whale of a time poking fun at these hapless, trigger-happy goons, but he never loses sight of the fact that a serious and somewhat grizzly tragedy sits at the centre of the film - not the murder, but the waning lives of Ebbing's miserable players.

Beneath the surface of an admittedly very thick, funny veneer of darkness is a series of tormented, confused souls who each get a chance to grapple with their own touching transformation, tragic misfortune, or both.
Slow burn but still quite intense drama, intelligent, funny.

After sweeping awards at the 2018 Golden Globes, Three Billboards Outside Edding, Missouri is not only nominated the Best Picture of the Academy Award but also currently deemed having the best chance of taking it home.
 
I finished the movie on a Sunday night, didn't expect much, but the dramatic tension was like a vortex sucking me inwards as the movie unfolds and the closer you were to the center, the more powerful it felt. The vivid depiction of characters, meticulously rendered storyline, implicit yet overwhelming emotion presented by the main characters, each of the above added together to form the solid structure of the movie. Yet, what captivated me the most was the conflicting human nature.
 
Mildred's aloofness and Dixon's toughness were their strongest shields which formed as they walk through thorns and thistles in life. But who we really are is a question we sometimes don't even know we are asking. 

Right vs wrong, evil vs righteousness, two scenes with one Dixon threw Red out of the window and another one where Dixon safeguarded the investigation file. Soft vs hard, warm vs cold, Mildred's response when Willoughby told her that he had cancer and Mildred's reaction when seeing Willoughby cough blood. It was so clearly presented that they are, and we all are, much more complicated than we think. One could argue that their personalities have changed. I prefer the idea of "to be, or not to be". The deepest question for a human soul to answer lingers on after the movie was finished with the final question asked: "Are you sure about this? (killing this man)". 

I wouldn't recommend the movie to those who want a chill night and a few laughs before going to bed on a Saturday night, but for those who are always exploring the deep conflict of human nature, it's not a movie you could bear to miss.

In a three-act structure, the second act tends to be the one where the good stuff is. Three Billboards outside Ebbing Missouri takes this to heart, beginning well after the murder that incites the action takes place and after the failed investigation has all but folded. Feeling the world is moving on from her still-burning rage, Mildred Hayes (Frances McDormand) rents the titular billboards, personally shaming police chief William Willoughby* (Woody Harrelson), who is dying of cancer and has perhaps the most screenwriterly name ever devised. The billboards scandal ripples throughout the town, perhaps nowhere more than in the police station, where the short-tempered, racist, and punnily-named deputy Jason Dixon (Sam Rockwell) gets angry seemingly on Willoughby's behalf. But the driving background behind each character, from Hayes' tragedy to Willoughby's illness to Dixon's racism, are all established quickly, sometimes awkwardly, through dialogue to cut to the chase. Director Martin McDonagh isn't interested in great tragedies nor is he particularly interested in police abuse. He's interested in how communities function, how defensive they can be to social upset, how putting their members into boxes begets violence. But maybe a bit of interest in the former would have helped.

Three Billboards has been marketed as a black comedy, but never finds an even tone, oscillating drastically between wallowing in melodrama and poking fun at bumpkins. Sometimes this tonal whiplash works: when Mildred's violent ex-husband escalates a situation only to have it defused by his young girlfriend cluelessly asking for a restroom, McDonagh keeps the scene going for a hilariously uncomfortable amount of time. At another moment, a sudden intrusion of Willoughby's illness during an interrogation provides the most intimate moment of the film. However, while a few of the performers find the right nerve to strike (notably the now-ubiquitous Caleb Landry Jones and Samara Weaving), many others never quite find it. Some, like Peter Dinklage's alcoholic salesman, serve one scene and otherwise hang out on the margins, which does give the town a nicely lived-in feel. But others, notably Abbie Cornish as Willoughby's far-too-young and implacably accented wife, feel air-dropped in from a movie-of-the-week. Compared to McDonagh's fantastically odd and dark In Bruges, Three Billboards is just too sincere to read as comedy.

Three Billboards commits to its second-act focus in the end, arguably cutting to black pre-climax. But before it gets there, it engages in some acts of forgiveness that have caused a fair amount of controversy, of which a lot of digital ink has already been spilled. A lot of it comes down to whether a certain act is read as redemption or a step forward, and for my money the film engages with the difficulty of redemption even after attaining self-awareness. It builds up a racial element only to unharmoniously sweep it under the rug, but it rather frankly asserts that atonement isn't simple. The parallels it draws between its two most broken characters are legitimately interesting, although handled less-than-deftly. Thanks to the character of Ebbing itself, it's certainly not a boring ride to get there. It's just not as riveting as the material could have been.

He viciously beats his audience with this kind of crap continually, and suffers no consequences for it. People actually love it (87%), and never ask about their assaulter. He may ride this all the way to a best picture Oscar. He even threw in a gratuitous punch to an innocent woman’s face, and the one young woman here was portrayed as a bimbo, because, you know. And the audience laughed at the midget jokes. The Oscar goes to....

A hard-nosed mother, at the end of her rope, rents a trio of billboards to remind local police that they still have no suspects in her daughter's seven-month-old rape and murder. Very Coen-esque, and not just in that it stars Frances McDormand, who's appeared in half a dozen of their films and is actually married to one of the brothers. Most notable is the way director/screenwriter Martin McDonagh (In Bruges, Seven Psychopaths) gets us familiar with dozens of rounded, colorful characters, fleshes them out and makes us care about how their paths intertwine. Or, in most cases, how they collide, break apart and ricochet into the next unsuspecting object. This really gets going in the second act, when a core character makes a profound decision that results in a solid hour of nonstop chain reactions. But it's not all dark gristle and angry monologues. Often, it works as an effective black comedy, which I realize is a tough thing to recognize after admitting it's about a rape investigation. Such tension-breakers are crucial, though, to keep us from getting too bogged down in the solemnity of it all, and to maintain a sense of momentum. Wonderfully shot, with plenty of time dedicated to exploring the beat-up small town at the center of all the drama, it's also expertly paced, brilliantly acted and continuously surprising. A deserved favorite for the Oscars.
This is easily one of the best films of the year. Beautifully shot, superb acting, and a great script, this is another excellent dark comedy from Martin McDonagh

3 anuncios por un crímen del director Martin McDonagh.
Nos cuenta la historia de una madre de un pequeño pueblo en Missouri a quién le violan y asesinan a su hija, un año y medio después el caso sigue sin resolverse por lo que decide rentar 3 letreros dirigidos directo al sherrif los cuales conducen a su casa para incentivar el caso de su hija. 
Puntos buenos: lo verdaderamente interesante de la película no es la trama, de echo nunca se resuelve el caso ni se deja en claro quién fue  el asesino, lo que si es lo mejor de esta película son los mismos personajes, está película tiene el mejor desarrollo de personajes que he visto en estos últimos años, en en verdad llegas a tener empatía con todos hasta el secundario menos usado tiene su carisma. De echo mi favorito de toda la película no fue la protagonista Mildred, fue Dixon este personaje que se dedicaba a ser un policía corrupto y racista quien  comienza como  antagonista toma completamente drástico en el cual si vida cambia, se arrepiente de sus acciones y se vuelve ayudante de Mildred para encontrar al asesino. Simplemente increíble. Además la fotografía es asombrosa y el soundtrack contribuye muy bien a las escenas.
Puntos malos: los efectos especiales aunque son pocos o casi nada, son muy malos y se ven muy falsos como la sangre en algunas escenas o el venado  y otra pequeña desventaja es que no es una película para todo el mundo, por lo menos a alguien que no disfrute de los elementos que mencioné se le ara una película muy lenta.
Pero fuera de eso recomiendo que si es posible vean esta película.

Pretty damn funny given the incredibly grim subject matter, but that's not a shock when you take into consideration that Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri is directed by Martin McDonagh, who once again comes away with a win, which makes him, in my opinion at least, three for three as a director.

McDonagh (In Bruges) revels in shoving tragedy and comedy right against each other, and he does so with immense ease and an awareness that that delicate balance of the two is what real-life is made of.  With Three Billboards, he's trying to marry that authenticity with a heightened sense of storytelling, specifically in the stylized dialogue and detailed characters. This exercise results in some inescapable messiness throughout the movie, yet there's so much compelling and highly entertaining filmmaking on display here you barely notice.
McDormand turns in a powerhouse performance as a vengeful Midwestern mom who buys three billboards in her town that shame local law enforcement for not doing enough to find the man who raped and killed her daughter. With dark subject matter and colorful humor bedding together, it's not an easy movie to take in. Yet despite the film's groove taking a minute to find, those complexities that make it difficult are what make it great. A lovely look at what small-town America really acts like, the characters' motivations and intentions are revealed slowly, and there's not a bad performance in the bunch. Harrelson's character is strongly upright yet deeply sad, and Rockwell brings immense depth to his racist, drunk Barney Fife role.
And the film's edges are as rough as its characters. Metaphors are thinly veiled, characters change when needed, subtext becomes text. However, because the movie, at its core, is just a morality tale, everything is there to support its main point: tragedy changes lives, but vengeance destroys them. And luckily that central message is more open-ended, allowing the movie to sit with its audience long after the individual issues have been washed away.

"Anger, Actually". A study of anger set against the backdrop of small-town america.  The characters are not so much likeable as understandable, each with their own demons and their own way of dealing with them. The action is almost preternatural, making it less a story about specific people but about asking what you might do in dealing with your own anger.  Peppered with as much humour as violence, I loved this film not just for being entertaining and moving but for questioning how to deal with your own anger when it's so easy to cause more pain.

The film never finds the right balance between the unbelievable and the real, between the comic jewels within this small town and the dark pain of its story. Take Woody Harrelson's police chief: How is this small town cop, whose department is filled with barely literate and admittedly racist (not to mention homophobic) mouthbreathers, so remarkably eloquent and intelligent? That fantastic element doesn't fit the rest of the frame. His answer to their racism is that being a good cop is all about "love"-yet how loving is it to only teach them that *after* you die, *after* the cop has thrown someone out a window and brutally tortured a POC? Oh, and let's get to that: The movie is racist. Not just the cops in the movie; the movie itself. All the suffering experienced by the black characters means nothing to them-they just bounce back with a smile, la-di-da, here I am back from a false arrest without another word to say for it-rather, it only occurs for the benefit of the white characters. And even then, the white characters don't quite grow from it, their redemption remaining utterly repugnant.

Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri, walks a tightrope between heartbreaking drama and dark comedy - expertly directed by Martin McDonagh - and features some of the best work of Frances McDormand's stellar career. Acting is first rate top to bottom, including Oscar-nominated work from Woody Harrelson and Sam Rockwell, but also smaller parts from Peter Dinklage and Lucas Hedges, who is having himself a pretty good year (he also shone in Lady Bird). Brutal violence, racism, love, hate, redemption.....they all take their turn in this brilliant drama. Destined to make my list of the Top 10 films of 2017. 4.5/5.

Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri ****
A desperate grieving Mother (Francis McDormond) takes a drastic step in order to put pressure on the local Police Department investigating her Daughter's murder by renting three billboards and erecting messages that taunt the Chief of Police (Woody Harrelson) lack of progress.
What unfolds is a gripping black comedy Drama that mixes moments of humour with instant moments of such humanity and sadness it becomes a impossible not to be absorbed undeniable into it's story.
?
This is a film that portrays itself as a "who done it" but makes that a brave choice to become a rich character study of people just trying to people in amongst the wake of tragedy and circumstance.

Doesn't sound a laugh a minute but honestly most of the time it is, establishing dark laugh out statements of pure angry and grief.


Whether McDormand is berating a Vicar, reporter of the chief of Police the foul mouthed rants are wonderfully written and delivered with fire.
That's another beautifully crafted aspect of the film are the tiny moments of the film's balance between rage and humanity. Whether amongst McDormond's hate filled mission she takes time out to put a upside down bug back on it's feet to screaming at the Chief Of Police than instantly finding common humanity amongst tradegy.
A story of good people all reacting to circumstances that life has handed them and acting accordingly the only way they know how from their grass roots.

It's truly a stand out out performance by Francis McDormand that has to earn her a Oscar Nomination she's frankly that good. Her face never stops working, when ever she's spoken to her face is still processing, expressing and captivating a woman in constant torment from the first shot to the end she's working 100%.
Woody Harrelson is on top form delivering a performance which like the film is comedic and sad with also one of the best character arks of the narrative along side Sam Rockwell as the racist child like deputy who does some growing up on the way.
This is storytelling unlike anything were normally used to from Hollywood. It's Bold, Engaging, Risk Taking Power House Drama that will surprise and leave you pondering long after it ends.
It won't be everyone's cup of tea but that is defiantly the point.
Frances McDorman's performance gripping, casting of a young woman as Woody Harrelson's wife ridiculous. Story line interesting and brutal at times.

One of the worst movies I've seen.  Terrible waste of great actors talent.  Full of racial cliches as well as terrible attempts at comedy in what should have been a serious movie about a horrific crime.

The good points?  The billboards, themselves, are effective (within the story, and as a plot device). The acting - most notably from McDormand, Harrelson and Rockwell, and other support is solid - is a strength.

"Okay" points: I didn't mind the ending itself, and really didn't want to see additional 'resolution' to this story...was happy it ended. I don't mind that they attempted humor, and was mostly okay with coarse language. At least, I'm not automatically turned off (or on) to it.

The bad points? Where to start. The humor just did not work. Very little of it provided relief and most of it was not too clever (even though fairly acidic in most cases) or appropriate to the situation. I think that this writer/director was MUCH too impressed with himself and did not care too much about the intelligence and conscience of his viewers, or about weighty issues that he "explored" in a half-assed way.  This was NO "Fargo" - an inventive masterpiece of dark humor. This movie - a quip or two aside - was not funny, and not humorous.

Lessons learned? In this town, you can hurl Molotov cocktails at a police station and almost kill the (racist scumbag admittedly, till his miraculous epiphany) former cop inside and suffer no consequences.  In this town, you can (if a racist scumbag cop) beat an innocent man almost to death in broad daylight across from the police station and suffer no consequences other than losing your job - and turning in your badge when you get around to it.  You can also (though kinda justified...kinda) kick high school students in their privates with no recriminations. And on and on...

This film mostly worked for me as I watched it, but as I reflect on it...just one day later...the script was bad, and it was written from a very dark place - without any real depth to it.

I think this film was a bit of a mess and will be hard to review because some of the bad things about the movie truned out to be the better side of the movie and some of the good things turned out to be of poor quality. First things first...when is this movie supposed to be set? the time period was very confused. The ambulance looked as though it was present day but some of the stylisation of peoples homes looked like it was from the 80's and 90's. On top of that some of the attitudes of the police charcters was like something out of the 1920's or 1950's. On that issue, I am sorry I don't believe that aspect of the story was true to life at all. That the police are these open racists modelled on something from the era of segregation. That aspect of the story was too far fetched. Yes there are racists in the modern times but they are subtle and hidden, not these 2-D predictable characters. I really like sam rockwell and he has a natural affinity for providing levity in films however I foud the humour in this film misplaced because the subject matter was so serious it felt out of place. On the good parts of the movie I thought the dialouge was excellent with some really funny lines invloved. There were really interesting characters also. The ending of the movie however is dreadful. To go through all that with such a depressing subject matter to be fobbed off with an 'open to interpretation ending' was a very dissapointing cop out. So in the end because the ending was so dissapointing I apprecited the humour in this movie more because there was nothing left to cling on to. Even although I didn't agree that a movie of such seriousness should have humour so prominent in it. I also thought at certain points the movie was going to be an SJW diversity feauturette but to be fair the movie turned it around and gave fair credence to everyone involved. Apart from all that a very confused movie with a really poor ending.

"All in all, Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri is as amazing as the length of its title. Martin McDonagh produces a multi-genre, thought-provoking screenplay with excellent pacing and tone control. He is also brilliant as the director, using long takes and the realistic setting to its advantage, making the movie even better and still counting with a memorable score. All-star performances from Frances McDormand, Woody Harrelson and Sam Rockwell take the movie to a whole other level, but with an ending that is not as great as it could be plus an annoying character (Penelope) that thankfully does not share much of the screentime"

One of the strongest contestants for these Oscars and likely to win Best Picture, since it already got the Golden Globe! It recounts how Mildred Hayes, portrayed by the excellent Frances McDormand, personally challenges the local authorities of Ebbing, Missouri to solve her daughter's murder when they fail to catch the culprit, by exposing their incompetence in three billboards asking for results. Sam Rockwell's Dixon is so hateable and lovable at the same time, but he definitely earns all his awards with that complex performance. The dark comedy is hilarious and the drama is strong. It is an angry film with a lot of aggressive behaviors but that's the whole point. Good Luck at this Awards' season!

THere are just SO many good things going on here , I could write a whole bunch about each of them, but here's a resume
1.  mordant, black humour that hits the mark time after time - funny in such a sympathetic and rounded way, but sharp as sharks' teeth
2. All-round excellent acting and direction- not a duff character in sight for the whole film- and some memorable characters - we loved Woody Harrelson as Willoughby and Sam Rockwell as Dixon but there's another 6 or more actors who just gave superb performances
3. really good plotting and script-writing - many times you expect one series of events, and get another, but in such a convincing way, and the characters just keep developing and becoming more complex and more HUMAN as you go- beautifully observed, and the film just doesn't let you get away  with easy binary thinking - you are pulled into the complex lives of humans- their motivations , actions and reactions, and you cannot help  but see them as PEOPLE, whatever your first reactions to the character are.
3. great cinematography - not a poor choice of shot on show
4. relevant- contemporary comment on modern America and historical tropes - 
5.  we want to see it again

GO see it folks, you can't go wrong

Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri

Surprisingly, the music is amazing in it, all the tracks are perfect and encourages each and every scene especially when the billboards are burned down, there are couple other scenes too but don't wanna spoil it. Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri has the perfect balance of character driven movie and script driven movie and addition to this, an unpredictable one. Martin McDonagh; the writer-director, brings out something new in this genre that has never been witnessed, he plays with his characters and tracks like he is juggling and even his short characters too will make you feel for them (Peter Dinklage and Caleb Landry Jones) which shows the range of the characters and the actors. Frances McDormand oozes power like never before; she is brutal, arrogant, sometimes wrong and surprisingly funny. Woody Harrelson is straight out stunning in it but the real trump card is Sam Rockwell; he almost has a parallel role to Frances and he justifies his presence till the last frame. Three Billboards Outside Ebbing Missouri stands out alone in its genre for its unpredictable script, brutal characters and amusing conversations.

Here is your assignment, class....there was a rape & a murder in a backward racist town.  Write a short story based on this topic, and add as much violence, racism, stupidity, hatred, irrelevance, & anger as you can.  If you incorporate all of these characteristics into a creative irrational plot, we  may turn your story into a feature film with great actors who can make audiences believe that this is a great movie.

Three Billboards has fantastic acting and a savvy plot in spades and while these are both necessary for a well-made, and reputable film, a consistent tone is a quality that is also important, and the Achilles Heel of this film. It wants to be both a black comedy and tragic drama, but these two genres never fluidly collide, making for an awkward and overall unsatisfying journey. One minute you are grieving for this woman over a very tough subject and the next, someone throws out a deeply unsettling attempt at humor. It all feels too darkly whimsical to give the story the proper due. I don't mind black humor, but I do mind a consistent tone and a more smooth meshing of the genres the film is aiming for. Those not familiar with the directors sensibilities will be left out in the cold and the affect of the film is one with a deep lack of an arc. Frances McDormand is brilliant but her arc is non-existent. Sam Rockwell is the most fleshed out in this film and he will deserve the awards he will undoubtedly win. One just wishes the film was better at telling its powerful story. Rating: 59

Three Billboards outside of Ebbing Missouri 

4.5/5- I saw this film last year but it has only recently come out on general release. This is an excellent film that revolves around a mum (Frances McDormand) who sets up three billboards that directly questions the local police chief (Woody Harrelson) as to why the killer of her daughter has not been brought to justice. The comedy is well toned but never overshines the dark subject matter. The film boasts a superb supporting cast of Sam Rockwell, Peter Dinklage and John Hawkes. You never know which way the story is going to go. You can get two or three judgements on each character once you see the situation from their point of view. This was one of my favourite films of last year. I urge you to go and see it.
Some of the best acting I have ever seen, with an astoundingly good script.

With a cast consisting of some of my favorite actors, "Three Billboards" takes a unique concept of a story, and focuses on aspects of characters that we don't normally see. It helps that Sam Rockwell delivers a vintage Sam Rockwell kickass performance. 

This film swears like a sailor unabashedly, almost to a distraction at times, but who gives a shit? It's an interesting look at characters affected by tragedy, while introducing levity in interesting places, and centering it around the premise of forgiveness. It might not deliver the things we're used to seeing in a movie, but it's a film that I think you should definitely check out.

Outstanding acting and a gripping story. Palpable the harsh contrast in this rural Southern Midwest town between physical space and liberty, for mind and psyche it´s pure claustrophia. In this community close to anarchy, only a new police chief from outside can bring back some discipline through strict authority. Thus all sympathies for the main character despite the flaws. Though I find it quite disturbing how subtle this film is romanticizing self-justice and the peculiar us american obsession and love for weapons, dangerous and frightening.

While I enjoyed much of the film, there were scenes which simply did not work. For example, when they are alone together the police sergeant's wife says to him, "You have a very nice cock, Mr Willoughby", to which he replies, "I recognise that line. That's from Shakespeare, I think." Which hands the punchline to his wife, "No. Oscar Wilde." That dialogue does not sound like small town backwoods America. It sounds like smart-ass educated Dublin - McDonagh's background. That is the trouble with writer-directors: the filters which remove bad dialogue are missing. Which is a pity, because one bad piece of dialogue can spoil the effect of many good preceding scenes.

First off, though I liked this movie I didn't love it. The performances and script are excellent, with unexpected turns. It shows the best and worst of human nature and the imperfect beings we are. While you can see Mildred's anger and grief at her daughter's death, this is demonstrated more in her taking drastic actions and isn't balanced with more vulnerable emotional moments. It is still a touching, as well as brutal, movie but is let down massively in my opinion by the ending. For me it didn't even feel like an ending, more like the picture cut out and you're still waiting for it. Maybe it was meant to be a clever ending, where we are left to wonder what will happen but it is the wrong choice in my opinion and didn't round off the characters' emotional journeys.

¿Hasta dónde sería capaz de llegar una persona para conseguir justicia? ¿Cuáles son los dilemas éticos y morales que estaría dispuesto a sobrepasar?  Estas son las incógnitas que plantea 3 anuncios por un crimen (Three Billboards outside Ebbing, Missouri, 2018), una de las películas que arrasó en los Golden Globes , incluyendo el premio a mejor película dramática, y candidatas a llevarse varios premios en la próxima entrega de los Oscars. La trama da inicio cuando Mildred Hayes (Frances McDormand) luego del asesinato de su hija adolescente decide colocar tres carteles al costado de la autopista dirigida al jefe de policía William Willoughby (Woody Harrelson) cuestionándolo por su falta de profesionalismo a la hora de investigar el crimen y buscar a los culpables. El simple hecho de la presencia de esos carteles en el pequeño pueblo campesino de Ebbing, Missouri, generará un gran caos y rechazo no solo por parte del departamento de policía sino también de gran parte de la población debido a los problemas de salud que afronta el oficial Willoughby, por lo cual por momentos la película no gira en torno al asesinato de la hija de la señora Hayes sino a las consecuencias de la mera presencia de los tres carteles.
Si hay algo que no le falta a este thriller es la presencia de humor negro con una gran cantidad de gags y situaciones políticamente incorrectas que permiten alivianar la situación que están viviendo los personajes. 
Es importante destacar las enormes actuaciones de Frances McDormand y de Sam Rockwell quien interpreta a Jason Dixon, un ebrio, violento y racista oficial de policía. Ambos obtuvieron estatuillas a mejor actriz y mejor actor de reparto en los Golden Globes y en los Critics' Choice Awards y tienen grandes chances de llevarse también un premio Oscar. 
#threebillboardsoutsideebbingmissouri

Three Billboard expertly navigates the fine line between comedy and darkness. It's a loaded story that would have probably been too hard to bear without the comedic spin. But can we talk about acting? Everyone aspiring actor/actress should be required to watch this movie. Frances McDormand, Woody Harrelson, and Sam Rockwell put on a show. I don't remember the last time I left the theater feeling this much in awe of the actors' performances. Three Billboards will completely overwhelm you and you will leave with a heavy heart, but you will also leave with smile from the glimmer of hope it offers.

A film that, on closer inspection, seems to be dissembling much more than it is revealing; distracting, much more than it is amplifying; an awful lot of sound and fury in the end signifying nothing.

Think of Ebbing, Missouri - not a real place, but selected as the more-or-less midpoint, north-to-south of the United States.  Think then of a racist character named Jason Dixon, and reflect on the Mason-Dixon line that once denoted the demarcation for the legality of slavery, once Pennsylvania outlawed it.  Conclude that this film must therefore be about race, and have important and weighty things to say about it; Ebbing, Missouri as microcosm, as synecdoche.

Think about the subversive-seeming scene where wooden structures are burning in a field in middle America.  But here there was no KKK.  It feels like that scene must be undercutting something, must be symbolic of something.  What is it symbolic of?

Think of Woody Harrelson, facing his own immediate mortality in the company of his horses.  Think about how that is symbolic, and of what.  Think of the deer appearing at Frances McDormand's side.  Again, ponder how it is symbolic, and of what.

Think about the specificity of the town name in the title - and think then about Fargo, North Dakota.  Think about Frances McDormand in the starring role.  Consider if there is any reason for this that is not utterly superficial.

Think of a character introduced reading Flannery O'Connor.  Think of Psycho - "no one comes this way anymore, since they built the highway".  Reflect again on where this film is positioning itself in a literary canon.

Consider the themes the film purports to be about - race; rape and murder; cancer; death; grief; vengeance.

Then reflect again.  You're being told at each turn that this film is of an oeuvre; is standing on the shoulders of giants.  You're distracted, again and again, by its referents, its indebtedness.  Examine closely what this film is actually about.  Is it about death?  About cancer?  What about racism?  Is it about vengeance?  About guilt?  About grief?  Think about what exactly about those things is explored, is revealed.

And then conclude, finally, that it is about none of these things.  Just because people die in the film does not mean it is about death.  Because someone has lost a daughter does not make it about grief, or guilt.  Subject matter alone cannot lend gravitas to a work - that comes in the reflections and meditations on these things that emerge from the film.  I see none at work here.

Just because a film-maker has seen the films of the Coens Brothers, or Alfred Hitchcock, or Tom McCarthy; or read the work of Flannery O'Connor does not mean he is their equal.  

A film whose ideas are murky, under-cooked; a film maker who knows what he wants to talk about, but without any idea of what he wants to say about these things; and hopes to disguise that truth with flag waving, with sleight of hand, with constant reminders of the works of artists who were clear about what they wanted to say.  This is the work of a confidence trickster - full of sound and fury, signifying nothing.

Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri is a darkly funny, intense, powerful film that carries a sharp wit and a dark underbelly. Irish writer/director Martin McDonagh has left his comfort zone and dived into the underbelly of rural America. It's not a perfect film, it has flaws but its strengths are considerable adding up an intoxicating thoroughly entertaining film. The biggest strength of the film are the performances. Frances McDormand is superb as the grieving mother of a dead teenager who tackles head on a police department she believes is under performing. One of the police officers is played brilliantly by the ever talented Sam Rockwell. His character is pretty deplorable but there is an interesting story arc in store for him. This film is about redemption and salvation. It's about inaction and the moral decisions we make. There are some story holes but it moves at a pace that still pleases. Dialogue is sharp and darkly funny and it is more poignant than I expected with some powerful scenes that affect the heart and the head. The film feels fresh and original which definitely makes for a great experience.

It takes a film that's small-scaled with a given decision to wait for a home viewing to instead be given a chance to see a theatrical viewing thanks to its growing, literally award-winning reputation, particularly during the helpful awards season. Presenting the latest dramatically crafty cinematic experience that proved theatrically worthwhile is "Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri".

The supposedly dark comic drama tells a crime story that rages war within a small town community between an unsatisfied mother looking for justice and the local law enforcement with a sympathizing, ailing chief. Around the aftermath months of her daughter's death and rape with no justice served due to no culprits turned in, Mildred Hayes (Frances McDormand) took a bold action of renting the three billboards along the town's entrance path with a controversial message directly addressed to the town's revered Chief Wilhoughby (Woody Harrelson). His second-in-command Officer Dixon (Sam Rockwell) becomes the bad cop when getting involved with a taste for violence and fueled the war-mongering flames between Mildred and law enforcement.

 You'll find "Three Billboards" a similar experience to a typical drama with the said dramatic craftsmanship and occasional expressions of the filmic power's peak, and it's the usual pick to hold it off till it's available for a home viewing. But that's the case of underestimating the value that turned out to have a perfect decent scale at the cinema. It's that good of a movie filled with tense and committed emotions along with a touch of unsatisfactory but passable truism, memorably by emotional impact with a gruesome point and sealed fate.

The only work I've seen of writer-director Martin McDonagh is his short film "Six Shooter", and his directorial skills from there had enlarged through the unseen "In Bruges" and this film under the consideration that it's easily his best yet with a unique scale that was presented. The atmospheric tone from still wide shots at different angles to a personal aroma perspective is expressed by the elegance in music, with the original score composed by frequent collaborator Carter Burwell (who deserved the current award-winning recognition). There's a sense of perfection in those scenes, stylized by excellent cinematography, with a fitting jukebox and charming score, displaying the usual powerful peak of one dramatic story with a continuous shot of harsh grief, and difference in lighting from after a pivotal flashback.

One of the few main factors that drawn me into seeing this film is the cast glorifying the reputation with their excellent performances into really good characterization. The performances of the cast really has a way of putting a spectator in their shoes within their spaces to separately feel their mentality and reacting to their actions that are gripping and unnecessarily irrational - with one action being formulaically predicted based on the heat of the case. The obvious standouts are McDormand and Harrelson, and Rockwell in particular as the latter radiated a lot of energy into his provoking actions while the former shows conflict in her ideal emotions that are understandable.

"Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri" excels with a storytelling value that teaches filmgoers to not underestimate one film by its scale. It consists impressive cinematography from craftsmanship and aesthetic direction that positioned the three billboards in a symbolic meaning, along with the human soul counterpart bringing out emotional performances from its excellent cast. Although it could've been rated higher if it weren't for the irrational acts despite that they proved pivotal to where it ended up and make the film beautifully powerful with grit, which genuinely makes this one of the very best of 2017. (A-)

Following my viewing of the Golden Globes, and more recently, the SAG awards, I decided that watching Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri would most likely be a good idea. The film has performed exceptionally well so far this awards season, consistently winning many of the awards it was put up for. After being fortunate enough to see it, I can understand why.

I feel it is worth quickly adding that, while watching this film, I was quite tired. I'd seen Coco earlier that same day, and I rarely go out for that long a period. The fact that the film still made such an impact on me in that state is impressive.

Ordinarily, this isn't the sort of film I'd be attracted to. I didn't really recognise many of the actors going in, nor was it based on an existing property. To put it bluntly, it was a proper, standalone film. After seeing it, I was genuinely impressed.

Ordinarily, I would list highlights of a film, then delve into the issues. Now, however, I'm perplexed; the film did everything well, at least to an extent. There was only a few things I found issue with. The CGI (which was used incredibly sparingly) was often rather jarring. It didn't fit with the rest of the gorgeously shot world. Though the locations are never astounding, Ben Davis makes even relatively mundane countryside look beautiful.

The characters shown within this film are rather fascinating. The events leading up to the film could almost be a film in themselves. Despite what reading a synopsis may imply, however, this film isn't a murder mystery. The murder of Mildred Hayes (Frances McDormand)'s daughter isn't the focal point of the film. Instead, the main focus of the film is how the event impacts various people, and how they go on to deal with it. Each main character is rather layered, and could arguably be the lead in their own film.

Bringing these characters to life is a brilliantly talented cast. Frances McDormand deserves each award she receives. I feel the trailer actually does her character a disservice; after watching it, I felt that she was simply a vulgar, hateful woman taking her frustrations out on those around her. In reality, she's a far more sympathetic character, who isn't nearly as abrasive as the trailer makes her out to be. Woody Harrelson's Chief Willoughby was probably my favourite character of the film, who, despite playing the straight man in many scenes, is able to bring levity and humour to the dark situations in which he finds himself. Sam Rockwell's Dixon is also wonderful, though many people have taken issue with his character's arc. Personally, I enjoyed it greatly, though it's something to note.

Many of the supporting characters are hit or miss. I feel Peter Dinklage was brilliantly funny, though some of the others failed to steal a chuckle from me. The rest of the audience seemed to enjoy them, however, so it's most likely a fault of my own.

I was pleasantly surprised by how violent this film is; the trailer makes it seem that violence is a punchline to a joke, but at times, the movie is genuinely brutal. It's probably more violent than most modern horror films.

The soundtrack was actually rather enjoyable. The original scoring was great, and fit the setting perfectly. The other songs added each served their purpose, oftentimes accentuating the comedy within a scene.

For the most part, I found the writing great. The characters spoke like real (if dramatised) people, though occasionally there was some odd lines.

To conclude the review, I feel this was a truly impressive film, and I understand why it's getting so many nominations. If you love film, I must recommend you give this one a watch. Thankfully, this isn't one you need to see in the cinema; I think it could work just as well on a smaller screen. If you need a concrete ending, however, you may need to steer clear; it's rather open ended. I feel Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri deserves a 9/10, and I look forward to seeing more films of a similar quality to this one.

Note: Going into the movie -- and for most of the way through the movie -- I thought this was based on a true story.  It isn't.  This probably colors my review some, but not completely.

Overall, what struck me is how much hate and anger there is in the movie.  There is tons of strong cursing, including using certain words that are pretty much never used in movies.  There is blatant racism.  There is homophobia.  There are dwarf jokes. It portrays law enforcement in a very negative way. There are multiple acts of extreme violence that are somewhat stunning to imagine.  You put all of this together and I just had a hard time enjoying the movie where pretty much all of the characters are vile.  Overall, it portrayed America at its worst touching on nearly every sensitive topic in society today.

The ironic thing is I like movies like Tarantino movies that have harsh language and tremendous violence. I think what made this movie less enjoyable is those movies tend to be fanciful and I don't think of them as reality, whereas this movie comes across like it is portraying every day life in small town America and, in that context, these things are hard to bear.

There were a number of strong performances, but I just couldn't enjoy the movie.  It was just too dark and cynical for my palate.

Three billboards outside Ebbing Missouri is a compelling, sombre yet at times funny drama/black comedy from writer and director Martin McDonagh. The story revolves around Mildred Hayes who is disillusioned with the local police forceâ??s attempts to track down her daughterâ??s killers. She rents 3 billboards where her daughterâ??s body was found to provoke the police into action. 
Firstly letâ??s start with the cast; Mildred who is played by Francis Mcdormand is a power house. She plays a very real believable character who takes you on this journey. All moments of real gravitas or levity are centred through Mildred so anything less than a stellar performance could sink this story. Francis â??performance is the centrepiece (rightly so) of this impressive indie film and cards on the table I believe she will win best actress at the Oscars in a few weeks. Sam Rockwell once again picks clever indie films and at times and at times steals most of the scenes he is in. He plays the sometimes deplorable Jason Dixon and at times ignorant police officer. What McDonagh and Rockwell managed to take this character on a journey from irredeemable to someone your almost feel for. Woody Harrelson gives a real heartfelt performance and is one of his better roles from recent memory.  The rest of the supporting cast including peter Dinklage are also on form here.
Martin McDonagh ultimately has written and directed beautifully one of my favourite films of 2018 and we are in January!! The story is simply gripping and it never goes into too much detail about Mildredâ??s daughters demise which I feel is a clever move. This film feels like there is no real resolution, no finish with a tidy bow on top which grounds this in reality and plays out exactly how this film needed too. 
To conclude Three Billboards is a film that has real heart that will make you laugh , cry and everything in-between.
Hard to watch in the best kind of way. Martin McDonagh has a gift.

Quello che mi ha colpito di più di questo pluripremiato film è stato senza dubbio l'incredibile lavoro svolto sul cast, sulla recitazione e sulla sceneggiatura. La strana e particolare storia ci porta in una realtà tutta nuova ambientata nel sud degli Stati Uniti, un luogo dove non si ha la percezione del giusto e del sbagliato, in cui nessuno ha un ruolo rassicurante. Non ci sono personaggi positivi, ognuno di loro dimostra a gran voce la profonda verità nascosta dentro l'essere umano, tema che mi ha ricordato molto le riflessioni sull'uomo dei fratelli Coen. Il difetto principale del film è un umorismo finto e convenzionale, che mi ha fatto storcere il naso più di una volta. Le emozioni arrivano soprattutto nella parte finale, in cui l'evoluzione degli splendidi personaggi raggiunge livelli inaspettati e nuovi. Mi aspetto grasse candidature agli oscar, soprattutto per attori e per la cinica sceneggiatura.

From the writer/director that brought you Seven Psychopaths and In Bruges, Martin McDonagh has made his finest film yet in 3 Billboards outside Ebbing, Missouri. It is the blackest of black comedies punctuated with genuine moments of anger, sadness, fear and suspense.

7 months after the death of her daughter, Mildred Hayes takes matters into her own hands placing controversial ads on three billboards outside her town of (you guessed it) Ebbing, Missouri. 7 months and not arrests for the murder of her daughter and her finger (and billboards) are pointed right at the widely respected chief of police Bill Willoughby. This sets off a chain of events that has consequences in store for all that have a part to play in the incident, from the grieving family to the clueless police force. 

This film has three standout performances that propel this film beyond its premise. Woody Harrelson is brilliant as the small town sheriff with the heart of gold, his humanity and rye humour ground you in the reassurance that while McDonagh is taking a far darker route than his previous two films, the rich vein of wit is still present in Three Billboards.

Sam Rockwell is one of the finest actors in Hollywood with an incredible depth of range in countless performances, this one could be his best yet. Rockwell, plays Jason, a local cop with a short fuse who causes more problems than he solves. 

Frances McDormand really shines in this film as Mildred, her harsh exterior and dry dialogue hides a woman who is deep in grief and she tows the line between these two things perfectly.

I honestly can't fault this film at any point, anyone who has seen McDonagh's two previous films will know the man is an impeccable writer who creates dialogue that actors would love to say on a daily basis. He has not yet put a foot wrong on the silver screen and this is probably his best film to date when he wants to make you laugh he does, when he wants to get you thinking you think and when he wants you gripped by visceral scenes of violence and suspense, you are on the edge of your seat. I can not recommend this film enough to anyone who has a passing interest in cinema, believe this is two hours not wasted.

A rare gem that I wish I saw before 2017 ended. 

After months have passed without a culprit in her daughter's murder case, Mildred Hayes (Academy Award winner Frances McDormand) makes a bold move, painting three signs leading into her town with a controversial message directed at William Willoughby (Academy Award nominee Woody Harrelson), the town's revered chief of police. When his second-in-command Officer Dixon (Sam Rockwell), an immature mother's boy with a penchant for violence, gets involved, the battle between Mildred and Ebbing's law enforcement is only exacerbated.

This was one of those Oscar buzz films that I had no information about prior. I knew nothing about this film other than the fact that numerous amounts of people had told me to watch this. As a film major now, I've done my best to watch everything I can, which has been especially helpful now with MoviePass. Anyways, if I had watched this film before the year 2017 ended, it would've easily made my top films list of the year, as it was certainly one of the best of the year. 

Talk about dark comedy because I wasn't expecting this film to have any laughs at all. The comedy is dark, vile, and crude but it works so well. It's easy to push boundaries but to push boundaries in a way that's actually funny and emotional, that's astounding. I was able to have plenty of laughs throughout this film but it never detracted from the story or the dramatic / emotional side of the film. 

Yes, this is one of those hybrid genres that works so fucking well. It's a comedy mixed with drama, mixed with emotional, mixed with dark, mixed with mystery. It's a character study and a thematic watch that never forgets what it is. It's able to bring all of these elements together without ever detracting from the other. That's such a rarity to have these days; a film that knows exactly what it is but still manages to breed together different genres and emotions. 

The screenwriting was absolutely brilliant in this film. It was unpredictable and an amazing way to tell a story. The dialogue was brilliantly written, along with the interesting characters and intriguing storyline. It's a great screenplay, one that I'm certainly not capable of writing (which isn't saying much). But I think this film will be able to be enjoyed for a variety of reasons, one being the screenplay.

Very well made, strongly plotted film with excellent performances from Frances McDormand, Woody Harrelson and Sam Rockwell especially, but a disappointing performance from Abbey Cornish. The small amount of black comedy does not make this a likable story however. It is a sad, depressing tale with hardly a vestige of hope offered to any of the central characters.

This is an intense experience. The "three billboards" in the title suit the focus of the film very fittingly in a number of ways. These billboards become instruments of the bereavement, frustration, and unrest in the heart of a mother (in a truly epic performance by Frances McDormand) whose daughter had been raped, burned, and murdered several months prior. The audience soon learns that the mother's afflictions are justified as these billboards and the message they are chosen to convey act also as a foreboding introduction to this troubled town and as a catalyst for further events to occur and ancillary tensions to brew. The town is centered around a corrupt and discriminatory police force that has neglected their difficult cases and have yet to find a resolution for the death of the mother's daughter. Simply through this, the billboards are transformed into an advertisement of grief, an intended wake-up call fueled through anger, a symbol of injustice on behalf of the Ebbing Police Department, which leads to what this film is really about. It focuses on and explores the effects of grief and injustice on people and the ones around them while highlighting the extent these people will go to make things right or even just to have closure. The film is very forward and blunt in expressing itself, enough to the point of even feeling a bit offensive. However, throughout the course of the film, things happen, and the audience comes to sympathize with these unforgiving characters and smile at their black humor. Through these feelings, a deeper moral in the film is translucently revealed in that perhaps what this town truly needs is its fair share of love and forgiveness, a realization that would have never come to light had it not been for those three billboards. This is a fantastic and powerful film, deep-rooted in its subject and determined in its message while also clearly and realistically aware that, like many murder cases, grief is never truly resolved. Definite Oscar Best Picture nominee here.

A rollercoaster that will warm you heart, tear it asunder and stitch it together with its every beat. A true testament to the human soul in almost every way and a slap on the wrist of my apparent complete inability to judge one's character. 

It is my perfect balance of bitterness, reality and loss with love, empathy and change. Whilst it won't provide you with the closure Mildred so desperately deserves the journey is certainly worth it and leaves us free to grant her what she so desperately needs. 

It's only shortcoming was its late to the party one dimensional villain, who stands out as such amidst its contemporaries. Even In Bruges's Harry had principles. I would however argue it serves well in your struggle to debate Mildred's closure. McDonagh however has tested our conscious before and it is commonly whether or not we think Colin Farrell should die.

So could it have been happier? Without a doubt, but should it be changed? That's up to you.

Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri ****

A desperate grieving Mother (Francis McDormond)  takes a drastic step in order to put pressure on the local Police Department investigating her Daughter's murder by renting three billboards and erecting messages that taunt the Chief of Police (Woody Harrelson) lack of progress. 

What unfolds is a gripping black comedy Drama that mixes moments of humour with instant moments of such humanity  and sadness it becomes a impossible not to be absorbed undeniable into it's story. 

This is a film that portrays itself as a "who done it" but makes that a brave choice to become a rich character study of people just trying to people in amongst the wake of tragedy and circumstance. 

Doesn't sound a laugh a minute but honestly most of the time it is, establishing dark laugh out statements of pure angry and grief. 

Whether McDormand is berating a Vicar, reporter of the chief of Police the foul mouthed rants are wonderfully written and delivered with fire.

That's another beautifully crafted aspect of the film are the tiny moments of the film's balance between rage and humanity. Whether amongst McDormond's hate filled mission she takes time out to put a upside down bug back on it's feet to screaming at the Chief Of Police than instantly finding common humanity amongst tradgedy. 

A story of good people all reacting to circumstances that life has handed them and acting accordingly the only way they know how from their grass roots.  

It's truly a stand out out performance by Francis McDormand that has to earn her a Oscar Nomination she's frankly that good. Her face never stops working, when ever she's spoken to her face is still processing, expressing and captivating a woman in constant torment from the first shot to the end she's working 100%. 

Woody Harrelson is on top form delivering a performance which like the film is comedic and sad with also one of the best character arks of the narrative along side Sam Rockwell as the racist child like deputy who does some growing up on the way. 

This is storytelling unlike anything were normally used to from Hollywood. It's Bold, Engaging, Risk Taking Power House Drama that will suprise and leave you pondering long after it ends. 

It won't be everyone's cup of tea but that is defiantly the point.

This is a powerful movie for anyone who mom or a parent. We see what happens to a desperate mother who is grasping for any hope.  Frances McDormand plays this character with so much depth. Anger, hope, sadness, hopelessness and so many more mixed emotions are there. She practically carries the movie all the way through.

Other supporting characters are not given much depth with the exception of maybe Sam Rockwell. The coping methods are probably not recommended and also at times very destructive to her and those around her.

The time and place is now and the movie does point out that the world is changing. It won't be long where Three Billboards is only meant for a specific time and a specific audience.

My wife and I finally checked out this Oscar front runner.  Sort of a black comedy in a Coen brothers style.  The movie starts off as advertised - a mother of a murdered teenage daughter, frustrated with the lack of progress in the case, puts up three billboard signs to embarrass the local authorities to try harder.  The story that follows is a fascinating but unpredictable story.  The characters seem stereotypical at first, but the screenplay fleshes out surprising stories about everybody.  There's a bit a violence but tension permeates almost every scene.  The cool part for me is that every time something looks like a Hollywood-like trope, the rug gets pulled out from under you.  I sensed that some in the audience were annoyed with that, especially at the end.  With full-fledged characters, the actors were stellar.  One of my top three movies this year,  My wife also enjoyed it, giving it 8/10.

Three Billboards Outside Ebbing Missouri is the 3rd movie directed by Martin McDonagh. And is about a woman named Mildred, who after the police in Ebbing Missouri fail to catch the culprit responsible for her daughters death and rape puts up three billboards asking the chief of police why there have been no arrest in this case. Now because its a small town everybody knows about them the next day. Now certain people are on Mildreds side and certain people are on the side of the police and this town has no problem saying quite a few inappropriate things. But when the spotlight is shown on them fpr being complacent in solving a very important crime while also not being as complacent when it comes to committing other crimes they dont like that. Now I was looking forward to Three Billboards Outside Ebbing Missouri because I absolutely adore Frances McDormand and I think Martin McDonagh is a very good director. And I have to say this is one of my favorite films of the year. What makes Three Billboards so great is that though it explores a lot of deep dark territory it has a suprising amount of dark humor to it. And because the film uses the element of dark humor to tell its story it makes it sort of easier to watch. Another great aspect to Three Billboards is the performances especially from France McDormand. This movie was hands down her best role since Fargo (1996). In all honesty they could not have gotten a better person for this role. In my opinion McDormand should absolutely wim an Oscar this year for this movie. Also Sam Rockwell is another actor in this film who does a great job. But not only because of his performance but because his character definitely has the best arc in this movie. But aside from McDormand and Rockwells performances the films suporting cast of Woody Harrelson, Lucas Hedges, Abbie Cornish, John Haynes, Peter Dinklage, and Kathryn Newton all do an excellent job as well. Now the best part about this movie is the fact that its completely unpredictable. Like there are literally times in this movie were you think you know where somethings going but it doesn't go that way. In fact while watching the movie I just stopped trying to predict where it was going because its that unpredictable. Now Three Billboards Outside Ebbing Missouri is absolutely not for everyone. And I say this because not only is the film dark and depressing. But because it is very politically incorrect. And though the film is politivally incorrect to prove ots point it can come off as offemsive to some. In fact some of the things that are said in this movie I was utterly shocked by with how they got away with. However you may not even care because the acting is so on point and the films story is so investing. Now I do have one flaw with this movie however its sort of a spoiler so I just wont say it in this review. In the end Three Billboards Outside Ebbing Missouri was excellent. The film was tense, it was emotional, and even funny at time (I'll admit i laughed more then i expected with this one). If you are looking for an original, well acted, unpredictable film with great characters and that will keep you guessing till the very end I highly recommend Three Billboards Outside Ebbing Missouri to you I gurantee you will not be disappointed.

Pretty and dumb. It was easy to ignore a lot of problems with the help of the sweeping shots of ... was it really shot in Missouri? I'd buy it -- beautiful spacial element to the movie. Unfortunately, that's one of the only things to recommend it. The tone was all over the place -- one minute it's store-brand Coen Brothers, the next it's JD Vance. The redemption arc for Rockwell's cop was at best troubling, and at worst unacceptable. The center of the story, from a plot perspective, was Mildred's relationship with the police (individuals and the force more broadly), but her character was totally incoherent on this fundamental lever. The police are overstepping in torturing black suspects and busting her friend for nonsense, but also need to create a national DNA registry? Her son should have had more to do, though the actor may not have been up to it. Every black character was a mannequin, existing only as an avatar to signal the goodness of various (white) townsfolk and not as characters in and of themselves. Finally, there too GD many characters. Are we really adding Peter Dinklage for two scenes and a whirlwind fight in the final act? Zoo girl? Cedric? It was distracting.

Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri is a great, very dark comedy with a superb cast that made me laugh, cringe, and tear up all at the same time. Francis McDormand played a truly broken, angry character that mourns the death of a loved one, and the strength she put into her character really showed. Woody Harrelson and Sam Rockwell also had some very funny, sometimes serious chemistry in the scenes that they were in together, and it was very entertaining to watch. Sam and Woody also performed wonderfully individually as well, and both of their characters really engaged me. One scene I especially loved involved Francis McDormand's character and a beautiful dear, and I am not going to reveal why, but it was heartbreaking and heartwarming all at the same time. Three Billboards was a very emotionally moving and powerful movie with a storyline full of twists and turns along the way, and although I did enjoy I, Toyna slightly more, this movie was truly a great cinematic experience. - 90%

Three Billboards Outside Ebbing Missouri takes place in a small simple town, where a divorced mother (Frances McDormand) puts up three mysterious billboards criticizing the police department in their small town. 

Three Billboards is directed by Martin McDonough. McDonough got his start in theater but this is his third feature film. Before this he has directed In Bruges and Seven Psychopaths and he has already developed a clear style. His scripts focus around very complex characters who find themselves in dark and at times humorous situations. 

McDonough has been able to get the very best out of his all star casts in each of his films and Three Billboards is no different. The cast is absolutely phenomenal in this film. Each plays off the next eloquently never stepping over each other. Each character's through line makes sense and feels honest to the character. They never do anything just to advance the story or to directly benefit any of the other characters. 

McDonough uses Carter Burwell once again to score his film. Burwell seems to have a grasp on the atmosphere McDonough is going for here and compliments it perfectly. My only slight qualm would be that there are moments where the score sounds eerily similar to previous scores Burwell has done for McDonough. Especially the score for In Bruges. 

It is very easy for people to be off-put by McDonough's writing style. It is excessively vulgar and has no sense of restraint. But his characters are honest and sincere. They feel real and they have important things to say. If you are not someone who generally enjoys this style I would still implore you to watch this film. Behind all the grittiness and ugliness there is a lesson of understanding and compassion that I think is more important than ever.

I really wanted to love this film after all the hype. To start with I really did. There was a 10/10 film in here and the first half of the film almost gets there. It should have been called Three billboards and three letters and then after the third letter has been read (less the whole firebombing scene), there could have been a neatly wrapped up ending within half an hour. Instead the second half of the film ends up with one contrived scene after another and the emotional crescendo flops with an eye rolling whimper. The open ending can sometimes work but absolutely doesn't. After creating such a convoluted and slightly soppy second half to the film, the plot becomes drained of intellect, so why then leave an open ending. The director has already nailed his emotions to the mast, so at least give us the stupid, rousing ending the film seems to be hurtling towards. Instead, having already created a ridiculous build up, the film then ends without the courage to let us know whether the characters have been truly reformed by the chaos that has preceded. Such a waste of such a promising start to a film.

Stellar cast, beautifully shot, great performances, terrible story and dialogue. In the vein of tough-guy westerns, most of the characters either believe heinous things or commit heinous acts; quite a few characters commit felonies and do not face any sort of consequence. The rape of a child is used only as a plot device, we do not experience her as a character or an individual aside from a clunky argument scene where the protagonist tells her daughter she wishes she got raped. The humanity is totally stripped from the victim and her character is used as a MacGuffin of sorts, and there is no resolution or redemption to any of the mess. Some powerful scenes were already in the trailer and made more sense out of context. Most scenes had characters who only felt what the scene called for them to feel at that moment, and the depth of their character was constantly undermined by the almost vignet-like quality to the scenes. At one point, the protagonist's ex husband makes an unexpected visit, her son is VERY enthusiastically excited for this unannounced visit, (he's in his late teens,) and this encounter turns into an almost brutally violent assault where the same son is prepared, almost as if it were normal, to slash his father's throat. Later, all characters behave as if nothing happened. This type of thing happens many times throughout the film.

This film is a consequence-free experience for every character, while the main plot device is allegedly an attempt at seeking consequences for perpetrators of injustice. The characters live in an unrealistic bubble.

A very well done film, with some truly memorable acting performances. Frances McDormand's Mildred Hayes is full of humor, pain, and restraint at various times; a masterclass, for sure. Woody Harrelson gives an excellent character turn with lots of heart; a performance that keeps on giving. But the hidden gem that you only discover in the third act is Sam Rockwell's performance as Jason Dixon, a stereotypical racist redneck cop that has the biggest arc of any character.

This film is written very well, except for a few times when characters seem much wittier than they should be, or a certain phrase pops up word for word from two characters with no real justification. There's a hell of a lot more comedy than you'd expect from a film about a mother demanding justice for a murdered child. 

The film is well shot, with a handheld camera used during a particularly unhinged action sequence, giving you a sense of the loss of control. 

It does have a slight twinge of Oscar Bait to it, and it's a bit on the nose with the social commentary, especially in the first act. As we go further into the story, the characters grow on you, thanks to the amazing acting performances by the supporting cast as well as the three mentioned at the top. This film doesn't telegraph where it's going. In many cases, when you get to a certain plot point, the past several beats make perfect sense. 

In summary, this is a superb film. The flaws I mentioned are nitpicks and very minor. Definitely recommend.

This is the perfect movie for understanding why there are 2 Americas today. When you know that the only real part of the movie are the billboards which were in a small town in the south, the movie becomes much more about how the writer (and I would imagine Hollywood in general) views rural and small-town America. I enjoyed the movie at first when I thought all the injustice in this town was being exposed (it was inspired by true events after all). However, it was so farfetched that I had to look it up. When I found out none of it happened, it just becomes the usual moral signaling from immoral Hollywood and specifically the writer Martin McDonagh. It's interesting all the stereotypes he uses as he tries to point out the injustice of stereotypes. One of the more notable ones was the scene with the Catholic priest. The overly romantic view of suicide really didn't sit well with me. The scene with the dentist was probably supposed to be funny, but was just unrealistic and extremely dark when you know it wasn't something that actually happened (but who cares since "no one cares about Dentists"). While I didn't like the messaging of the movie, the elements of movie making were done well. If you have the same hopeless view of life as McDonagh, then you'll probably love it as the main character uncompromisingly backs down from no one while taking on all manner of abuse and injustice.

I'll give it two stars because the Sam Rockwell knocked it out of the park, but the film itself is just a mediocre production pretending to be something special with the same oscar buzz generated by critics from its viewing in the film festivals. Moonlight last year suffered from the exact same effect. 

The whole premise of the billboards is just plain dumb; she singles out the police chief for not making arrests when there was zero evidence to convict anybody. That's literally how the law works. He tells her this and she doesn't offer any valid solutions. And yet despite this, and despite the fact that the person she singled out is dying, she still keeps the boards up, coupled with her generally shitty attitude, just makes one care very little about this protagonist, who we're supposed to sympathise with (I think??).

Furthermore, the film shifts backwards and forwards in tone so much that its hard to distinguish exactly what its trying to be. There were scenes that were so crazy in the sense that I think they were played for comic value, but they just came across as awkward and bizarre. At one point, Dixon, walks right across the street, beats a kid up to a pulp and throws him out of the window, in front of not only several witnesses including the police chief, but his own police station, before returning and closing the door. He was later reluctantly fired. Fired. Sorry, but that man would have been arrested on the spot for battery and attempted murder. I know corruption, negligence and police brutality is a problem in the states, but that whole scene was just straight up bonkers. Furthermore, this very same character suddenly develops a redemption complex that we're supposed to sympathise with, and its so out of left field that its just plain confusing.     

What's more is that the film tries to bring up themes like racism, but instead of actually providing much needed commentary on it, it just merely mocks the fact that one of the officers was known to be a white supremacist who beats up black people and gets away with it. The actual concept of these actions is literally used in a scene for comedic effect. This, coupled with the fact that they brought Peter Dinklage (a bloody good actor) in just so they could throw around some midget jokes for kicks, shows you the level of competence in the humor department for this film. 

The more I think about this film, the more I dislike it. Even the name is pretentious. Don't be fooled by the buzz.

Performances are all good - with the exception of Abbie Cornish, who is utterly miscast and bewildering in her scenes - and Rockwell and McDormand are, of course, brilliant. But this film is way to serious and dark to be considered a comedy, which is fine - but it was advertised as a whacky, offbeat laugh-a-minute romp. 3 Billboards is amusing at best, sombre for the most part (which is fine, but I wish they had sold it that way) and although quite original, it doesn't quite pay off emotionally. Seven Psychopaths was far superior.
